1
Introduction
Petroleum systems associated with buried volcanic rocks and structures have recently attracted increased attention, to a large extent driven by success in China and Argentina, such as the discovery of 3.5 Tcf of gas in volcanic rocks in the Songliao Basin (Sruoga and Rubinstein, 2007; Feng, 2008; Feng et al., 2014; Wang and Chen, 2015). Similar to other discoveries in eastern China, petroleum in the Songliao Basin is typically within or associated with buried volcanic structures related to Mesozoic to Cenozoic rifting (Feng et al., 2014; Ye et al., 2017). Due to their architecture, petroleum systems in these buried volcanic edifices are fundamentally different from those associated with Paleozoic, tectonically overprinted and weathered systems, such as occur in western China (Feng et al., 2014), or with extensive basaltic magmatism and siliceous large igneous provinces (Rohrmann, 2007; Sruoga and Rubinstein, 2007). The sheet-like morphologies of large igneous provinces with extensive lava flows often act as regional seals with significantly greater prospectivity associated with sub magmatic traps than the relatively small igneous reservoirs (Rohrmann, 2007). In western China, due to post-magmatic tectonism, uplift and erosion, the original volcanic structures and facies successions are not well preserved and commonly separated from the cover sequence by a pronounced unconformity (Wenzhi et al., 2009). In contrast, examples of well-preserved Cretaceous and younger buried stratovolcanoes exist in offshore New Zealand sedimentary basins and are imaged by seismic reflection profiles (Bergmann et al., 1992; Bischoff et al., 2017, 2021; Infante-Paez and Marfurt, 2017; Morley, 2018; Kumar et al., 2019). In the Taranaki Basin buried volcanoes of Miocene age have arc affinities (King and Thrasher, 1996; Seebeck et al., 2014), a setting that is not commonly targeted for petroleum exploration globally. Nevertheless, non-commercial oil has been found within volcaniclastic rocks in one of these edifices, the Kora volcano in offshore northwestern New Zealand (Arco Petroleum New Zealand Inc., 1988; Bergmann et al., 1992).
Volcanism and associated rocks, structures and processes can affect all petroleum systems elements, including reservoir and seal formation, and petroleum generation, migration and accumulation. Volcanic and associated epiclastic rocks vary widely in their physical properties. Depending on the volcanic lithofacies and the degree of alteration and burial they can be either potential seals or reservoirs (Wu et al., 2006; Wang et al., 2015; Wang and Chen, 2015; Zheng et al., 2018). Processes such as mineral alteration can either destroy or increase porosity and permeability in volcanic rocks and surrounding sedimentary rocks (Wu et al., 2006; Tari et al., 2021), while fracturing often further enhances permeability and reservoir capacity (Magara, 2003; Jiang et al., 2017). In addition, dissolution during subaerial exposure can further enhance the porosity and permeability of volcanic rocks, improving reservoir quality (Zou et al., 2012; Ye et al., 2017; Heap and Kennedy, 2016; Jiang et al., 2017; Bischoff et al., 2021). Conversely, volcanic rocks can also provide sealing properties, particularly in rock types such as fine-grained tuffs, lithologies altered to bentonite, massive and non-fractured lavas or coherent subvolcanic igneous rocks (Wu et al., 2006). In other cases, overlying mudstones burying the volcanic edifice are reported to have provided a sealing cap for hydrocarbons (Magara, 2003).
Along with the complex architecture of reservoirs and seals within buried volcanoes, styles of petroleum entrapment can vary widely. Traps directly associated with the volcanic plumbing system can be formed by petrophysical contrasts between igneous rocks and their enclosing strata, as well as by deformation of pre-magmatic sequences due to the emplacement of shallow intrusions (Wu et al., 2006; Bischoff et al., 2017). These intrusion-related traps are often considered to be challenging petroleum exploration targets as rocks below volcanic edifices tend to be poorly imaged in reflection seismic data (Bischoff et al., 2017). Structural and paleogeomorphic traps related to buried volcanic edifices typically form by doming and deformation of pre and syn-magmatic strata and draping, differential compaction and faulting of overlying sedimentary successions (Bischoff et al., 2017; Kumar et al., 2019). Sedimentary traps include onlap and lateral pinchout of sedimentary strata onto the volcanic edifice (Bischoff et al., 2017; Infante-Paez and Marfurt, 2017). Coarse clastic deposits from subaerial erosion of the volcano may provide reservoirs that are sealed by marine mudstones and shales deposited during the burial phase. In addition, volcanic activity is commonly related to extensional faults that may have been exploited by the magma (Tibaldi, 2015; Morley et al., 2018). Faulting may result in offset of reservoirs and provide migration pathways for petroleum accumulation within volcanic edifices (Feng et al., 2014; Wang and Chen, 2015).
In addition to providing structures and mechanisms for petroleum entrapment, volcanism may also play a role in petroleum generation due to heating during magmatic activity and by increasing the thermal gradients near the volcanic edifice (Mørk and Bjorøy, 1984; Magara, 2003; Holford et al., 2013; Infante-Paez and Marfurt, 2017; Kutovaya et al., 2019). Magmatic heating may either increase the prospectivity proximal to volcanic edifices by inducing maturation of an otherwise immature source rock or could lead to early overmaturation and source rock depletion around the volcano. Early generated petroleum may leak to the surface rather than accumulate in traps. Venting of greenhouse gases, particularly methane, derived from magmatic heating of organic-rich rocks can have a strong natural contribution to climate fluctuations (Kroeger et al., 2011; Heimdal et al., 2021). For example, it has been argued that on a much larger scale, heating of Cretaceous organic-rich rocks through extensive sill emplacement along the North Atlantic margin could have been one of the driving mechanisms for the Paleocene‒Eocene climate maximum (Dickens, 2004; Svensen et al., 2004).
In this study we examine how the emplacement and burial of a stratovolcano can impact the maturation, migration, entrapment and leakage of petroleum in sedimentary basins. We analyse the petroleum system associated with the buried Kora volcano in northern Taranaki Basin offshore northwestern New Zealand (Fig. 1
) using 2D basin modelling. The Kora volcanic edifice is of particular interest due to the discovery of oil on its eastern flank (Arco Petroleum New Zealand Inc., 1988) and possibly related gas leakage suggested by bright spots above the apex and the flanks of the buried volcano (Infante-Paez and Marfurt, 2017; Kutovaya et al., 2019, Fig. 2
). The architecture of the volcano, it's age and lithological composition has been well studied (Bergmann et al., 1992; Bischoff et al., 2017, 2021; Morley, 2018; Kumar et al., 2019). Previous modelling has addressed the thermal evolution and impact on petroleum generation (Stagpoole and Funnell, 2001; Kutovaya et al., 2019). Here, we focus on the petroleum plumbing system and potential of the buried Kora volcanic system as an analogue for petroleum systems associated with buried volcanoes globally. We investigate whether seismic reflection indications of gas trapped in strata overlying the Kora volcano may be related to fluids that leaked from the volcano and indicate an active petroleum system and seepage to the surface.

1.1
Geological setting and basin evolution
The Taranaki Basin is a Cretaceous‒Recent sedimentary basin situated largely offshore of New Zealand's North Island (Fig. 1). Two-phase rifting initiated the formation of the basin in the mid-Cretaceous and led to the separation of Zealandia from Gondwana in the Late Cretaceous (Gaina et al., 1998; Strogen et al., 2017). Terrestrial sandstones, mudstones and coal measures of the Rakopi Formation and the Wainui Member of the North Cape Formation were deposited in NW-trending rift grabens that accommodate up to ∼4000 m of sedimentary strata (King and Thrasher, 1996; Raine and Schiøler, 2012; Strogen et al., 2017, Fig. 3
). From the latest Cretaceous onwards, marine deposits of the North Cape Formation transgressed over most of the Taranaki Basin. The northern part of the basin was dominated by deposition of distal fine-grained marine sediments of the Turi Formation through most of the Paleocene and Eocene (King and Thrasher, 1996). Intercalated into the Turi Formation is a 10–26 m thick oil-prone black shale unit, the Waipawa Formation (Killops et al., 1994; Sykes, 2008; Naeher et al., 2019), which is thought to have been deposited during a phase of climatic cooling and falling sea-level in the Late Paleocene (Hollis et al., 2014). The Turi Formation is overlain by sandstones of the Tangaroa Formation that were deposited as deepwater turbidite fans during a Late Eocene sea-level lowstand (Gresko et al., 1992; King and Thrasher, 1996).
When the convergent plate boundary between the Australian and Pacific plates initiated in the Late Paleogene, most of the Taranaki Basin became initially starved of clastic input resulting in the deposition of carbonate-rich rocks of the Tikorangi and Taimana formations in the distal part of the basin (Strogen et al., 2014a). During the Miocene‒Recent the evolving plate boundary resulted in widespread hinterland uplift and the deposition of deep marine mud-dominated strata of the Manganui Formation (King and Thrasher, 1996; Bull et al., 2019). Sedimentation rates increased from 12 Ma onwards, when, after initial reverse faulting mainly at the eastern basin margin, extensional grabens formed in the northern Taranaki Basin (King and Thrasher, 1996). Miocene-Pleistocene normal faults partially re-activated N–S oriented Cretaceous‒Paleocene normal faults (Giba et al., 2010), culminating with the opening of the Northern Taranaki Graben, a NNE-trending intra-arc rift system active from the mid Miocene to Pleistocene (Pilaar and Wakefield, 1978; King and Thrasher, 1996; Giba et al., 2010). During the Pliocene and Pleistocene, rapid shelf progradation resulted in the deposition of large, up to 2 km thick prograding foresets, overlain by relatively thin shelfal deposits (Hansen and Kamp, 2006; Salazar et al., 2015; Anell and Midtkandal, 2017).


1.2
Volcanism
The evolution of Zealandia throughout Cretaceous‒Recent times was accompanied by widespread igneous activity (Timm et al., 2010; Bischoff et al., 2020; Barrier et al., 2021). In Taranaki Basin, syn-rift Cretaceous volcanism occurred seaward of the present-day Taranaki Basin shelf (Fig. 1), forming a series of large (>5 km3) volcanic complexes aligned with concurrent Cretaceous faults (Bischoff et al., 2020; Uruski, 2020). The Paleocene-Eocene is characterized by clusters of small-volume (<1 km3) volcanoes, likely associated with the widespread Cenozoic intraplate volcanic activity in Zealandia and western Australia (Bischoff et al., 2020; Mortimer and Scott, 2020).
Miocene volcanism in the Taranaki Basin started at ca. 19 Ma and became widespread from 16 Ma (Giba et al., 2013). Volcanic centers are aligned NE‒SW, parallel to the Hikurangi subduction margin east of New Zealand, where the Pacific plate is subducted beneath the Australian Plate (Giba et al., 2013; Seebeck et al., 2014). Subduction-related volcanism was dominantly of basaltic-andesitic calcalkaline composition and associated rocks display a typical island arc geochemistry (Bergmann et al., 1992; Seebeck et al., 2014 and references therein). The NE‒SW alignment of the volcanic arc has rotated by about 50° from earlier, NNE‒SSW oriented activity that started at ca. 25 Ma (Seebeck et al., 2014). Since the Late Miocene, the arc migrated south-eastward due to slab roll-back to the present-day position in the Taupo Volcanic Zone and its NE extension (Seebeck et al., 2014; Mortimer and Scott, 2020, Fig. 1). Miocene volcanic activity in northern Taranaki Basin pre-dated the onset of widespread normal faulting, and although during the Late Miocene it was coeval to faulting, there is limited evidence for direct interaction with regional faulting (Giba et al., 2013). Instead, some volcanic edifices, such as Kora, are associated with Cretaceous rift-related normal faults, and ascending magma may have exploited these zones of weakness (Morley, 2018). However, in addition to re-activation of some of the Cretaceous faults in the Miocene, NE‒SW oriented or radial faults (e.g., Kora volcano) are locally associated with volcanic edifices (Giba et al., 2013; Morley, 2018; Bischoff et al., 2017, 2021).
K–Ar dating of volcanic clasts suggests that igneous activity at Kora may have started as early as 19 Ma (Bergmann et al., 1992). However, Ar–Ar dating of in-situ phenocrysts and biostratigraphic ages from strata underlying volcanic rocks suggest that the main activity was between 16 and 12 Ma (Bergmann et al., 1992). Activity resulted in doming of pre-magmatic strata and radial extension due to magma emplacement in the upper crust (depths <∼5 km) and the formation of a stratocone consisting of a central vent and several parasitic vents (Bischoff et al., 2017). Extrusive rocks comprise pyroclastic deposits interbedded with epiclastic sedimentary deposits (Bischoff et al., 2017, 2021). Volcanic activity was also accompanied by the emplacement of multiple sills and dikes beneath Kora's edifice (Bischoff et al., 2017; Morley, 2018; Kumar et al., 2019). During its activity, Kora formed a stratovolcano that may have risen from the deep marine seafloor to an elevation near or above sea-level (Bergmann et al., 1992). After activity ceased at ca. 8 Ma, the cone was partially eroded and eventually buried by marine strata during northward progradation of the Taranaki shelf (King and Thrasher, 1996; Bischoff et al., 2017; Bull et al., 2019).


1.3
Petroleum systems elements of the Kora volcanic system
The Taranaki Basin is New Zealand's only petroleum producing basin, with all commercial discoveries situated in the central and southern part of the basin, whilst wells in northern Taranaki Basin were dry or made only non-commercial discoveries. Several volcanic centers have been drilled, including the Cretaceous Romney structure in the deepwater Taranaki Basin seaward of the shelf (Romney-1; Rad, 2015, Fig. 1) and prospects related with the Miocene volcanic arc such as Mangaa and Albacore (Fig. 3). An oil discovery was made by the Kora-1 well, drilled on the eastern flank of the Kora volcanic structure in Miocene volcanic and epiclastic rocks, with additional oil shows in the Eocene Tangaroa Formation (Fig. 2). Oil in Miocene rocks in the Kora-1 well initially flowed at high rates of 1168 barrels per day, and, as tested by the Kora-1A sidetrack well at 668 barrels per day in a long-term test (Arco Petroleum NZ Inc, 1988). However, the 25 m column accumulation, with an estimated 15 MMbbl of oil in place (OMV New Zealand Ltd, 2011), ultimately was not deemed commercial. The discovery nevertheless led to the drilling of three further wells. Kora-3 and -2 in the eastern flank and near the crest of the volcano also encountered oil shows whereas Kora-4 in the southwestern flank was dry (Bergmann et al., 1992).
Late Cretaceous rift-related coal-measures of the Rakopi Formation are the most widespread source rock in Taranaki Basin and sourced the largest petroleum discovery in Taranaki Basin, the >6 Tcf Maui Field (Sykes and Snowdon, 2002; Sykes et al., 2012; Kroeger et al., 2021). Similar deposits are likely present in the Cretaceous rift strata in northern Taranaki Basin (King and Thrasher, 1996, Fig. 3). By contrast, the Kora-1 discovery has a clear marine signature and was typed to the Late Paleocene Waipawa Formation (Killops et al., 1994; Sykes et al., 2012).
The Kora-1 well targeted the Tangaroa Formation that generally contains good quality reservoir sandstones. However, the interval drilled in Kora-1 had relatively poor reservoir quality with porosities of 10% due to cementation related to hydrothermal fluid circulation (Bergmann et al., 1992; OMV New Zealand Ltd, 2011). By contrast, good reservoir properties were identified in volcaniclastic rocks within and around the Kora volcanic edifice. Volcaniclastics successions form aprons on the flanks of the domed edifice and consist of sets of interbedded primary volcaniclastic and epiclastic deposits (Bischoff et al., 2021). The primary volcanic lithofacies consists of non-welded crystal-rich lapilli tuffs and tuff breccias. These are composed of large plagioclase and amphibole phenocrystals and fragments of volcanic rocks typically immersed in a fine to medium ash matrix. Epiclastic conglomerates typically consist of poorly sorted, sub-rounded volcanic clasts in a microcrystalline tuffaceous matrix. These primary and secondary volcaniclastic layers are generally massive or weakly bedded. Epiclastic deposits have an average porosity of 23% and up to 997 mD permeability, slightly higher than the porosity and permeability of primary volcaniclastic rocks (Bischoff et al., 2021). The high porosity of these rocks is primarily a consequence of extensive secondary mineral dissolution and fracturing. Tuffs are interbedded with epiclastic deposits throughout the Miocene syn-magmatic interval drilled by Kora 1/1A. In the lower and upper part of the 800 m thick succession, epiclastic rocks are more dominant whereas in the middle part, Tuffs dominate (Fig. 2). The uppermost 4 m of the succession is formed by a marine sandstone consisting of reworked rounded volcanic clasts and bioclastic grains in a tight micritic matrix. This rock is well cemented but also contains pervasive fractures that increase porosity and permeability to over 10% and >0.1 mD, respectively (Bischoff et al., 2021). No lavas or subvolcanic rocks were intersected by wells and their extent and properties are unknown.
The Miocene volcanic and epiclastic rocks of the Kora stratovolcano are overlain by marine mudstones. However, the seal capacity of these mudstones is considered to be limited to a support an oil column of 40–120 m, in part due to limited overburden (Bergmann et al., 1992). In addition, multiple faults offset the volcanic edifice and seal rocks, providing potential pathways for fluid migration and reservoir leakage (Bischoff et al., 2021).


1.4
Petroleum systems modelling
A 2D basin model (Figs. 1 and 2) has been constructed using PetroMod v. 2020 software (Hantschel and Kauerauf, 2009) and a seismic profile from the Kora 3D seismic survey (PGS Geophysical, 2015). The modelling consists of four key components (model construction, thermal modelling, petroleum generation modelling and petroleum migration modelling), with the methods and data underpinning each discussed in the following sections.


1.5
Model construction
The 2D model was constructed using inline 1250 of the pre-stack depth migrated Kora 3D survey (PGS Geophysical, 2015) across the center of the Kora volcanic edifice and intersecting the Kora-1/1A wells. The data have a dominant frequency of 45 Hz, corresponding to a vertical resolution of up to 30 m near the crater (Kumar et al., 2019). Reflection seismic data were depth migrated using Kirchhoff 3D pre-stack depth migration and calibrated using horizon picks in the Kora 1 to 4 wells (PGS Geophysical, 2015; see comparison of seismic reflection data with GR wireline log data of Kora-1 in Fig. 2). We have interpreted 16 seismic horizons in the seismic inline to define the geological architecture and to constrain the burial history in the model. The stratigraphy and ages of the mapped horizons are based on Bergmann et al. (1992), King and Thrasher (1996), Bland et al. (2013) and Strogen et al. (2014b). The stratigraphic framework was used to forward-model the evolution of the basin and the volcanic system from the Cretaceous to the present-day. The distribution of sedimentary and volcanic units was mapped from seismic data, following seismic volcano-stratigraphic principles and previous interpretations presented in the literature (Holford et al., 2012; Planke et al., 2015. Bischoff et al., 2017, 2021). Facies interpretation was supported by well log and core data from the well (i.e., Kora 1/1A) intersected by the model (Arco Petroleum NZ Inc, 1988; Bischoff et al., 2021). Lithological composition and properties assigned to sedimentary facies and volcanic lithofacies (Table 1
) are based on available well data and previous Taranaki Basin models (Funnell et al., 1996; Kroeger et al., 2017; Bischoff et al., 2021) as well as data from Kora-1/1A (Arco Petroleum NZ Inc, 1988; Bischoff et al., 2021). Lithological properties define the modelled compaction during burial according to Athy's law (Athy, 1930). For volcaniclastic rocks, scenarios were computed using either a standard compaction model or a model with increased porosity due to secondary processes (Tables 1 and 2
). The subsidence of the basin and the impact of magma emplacement and evolution of the volcanic edifice was modelled by adjusting the paleobathymetry, using the geometry of the mapped surfaces as a proxy for water depth and the age of a given horizon.


1.6
Thermal modelling
To constrain the timing of source rock maturation relative to the evolution of the volcanic edifice and the formation of reservoirs, seals and traps we have reconstructed the thermal evolution of the basin. The thermal model was calibrated using corrected bottom hole temperature (BHT; Funnell et al., 2007), drill stem test temperature (DST, Clayton, 2011) and vitrinite reflectance data at Kora-1 (Analabs, 1988, Fig. 4
). Vitrinite reflectance data below 3200 mbsl reach values of 1.47–1.57% Ro (Fig. 4). Previous modelling suggested that these high values are related to volcanic heating (Kutovaya et al., 2019).
The thermal basin model is constrained by boundary conditions defined at the seabed and the model base at 10 km depth derived from earlier models (Kroeger and Funnell, 2012; Kroeger et al., 2013, 2017). The derived heat flow at the base of the model during the Cenozoic varies between 54 and 60 mW/m2
(Fig. S1). Seabed/surface temperature is based on Ridgway (1969), Hornibrook (1992) and Hollis et al. (2014) and varied between 4 and 25 °C (Fig. S1). Magmatic heating was modelled using the intrusion tool in PetroMod™ with properties derived from Lesher and Spera (2015) and Kutovaya et al. (2019; Table 3
). Andesite intrusions were modelled to occur as single events at 14 and 12 Ma replacing sedimentary rocks in areas where igneous rocks are interpreted from the seismic data. Heating of adjacent rocks is assumed to occur exclusively by conductive heat transfer from the intrusive rock bodies. The cooling history of the igneous rocks and associated heat transfer is modelled using the thermodynamic properties specified in (Table 3). To compare the impact on the thermal history and petroleum generation, scenarios with and without magmatic heating were computed (Table 2). Doming implies that magma was also emplaced in the Cretaceous part of the sedimentary succession or the Upper Crust. However, reflection seismic data do not resolve such an intrusion (Bischoff et al., 2017). Previous modelling suggests that thermal effects of a deeper intrusion are not resolvable in well data, as the effect of subvolcanic intrusive heating on vitrinite reflectance would have overprinted the smaller effects of regional heating related to deeper magma emplacement (Kutovaya et al., 2019; see further discussion below). Regional changes in heat flow during Miocene magmatism are already incorporated in the model of Kroeger et al. (2013), which is used as the input for crustal heat flow.


1.7
Petroleum generation modelling
Two potential petroleum source rock intervals have previously been proposed to be present in the area, Late Cretaceous terrestrial coal measures and the Late Paleocene marine Waipawa Formation (King and Thrasher, 1996; Stagpoole and Funnell, 2001). The seismic character and geometry of a highly reflective interval in the Late Cretaceous succession adjacent to a fault related to Cretaceous rifting suggests the presence of coal measures and possibly later magmatic intrusions (Bischoff et al., 2017; Infante-Paez and Marfurt, 2017; Kumar et al., 2019; Morley, 2018, Fig. 2). Late Cretaceous coal measures of the Rakopi Formation and the Wainui Member of the North Cape Formation have been drilled by the Tane-1 well (King and Thraher, 1996; Raine and Schiøler, 2012) and widely mapped across the northern Taranaki Basin (Arnot and Bland, 2016, Fig. 3). The up to 1500 m thick high amplitude interval on the flanks of the Kora structure (Fig. 2) is likely related to the Rakopi Formation, rather than the thinner Wainui Member of the North Cape Formation. However, regardless of strong indications, the presence of the Rakopi Formation in this region is unproven, and fluids generated from Late Cretaceous source rocks were so far not encountered in northern Taranaki Basin (Sykes et al., 2012). We therefore model scenarios with and without presence of a Rakopi Formation source rock (Table 2). To model petroleum generation in the Rakopi Formation we use Pepper and Corvi (1995) type III DE organofacies kinetic parameters, as in previous models (e.g. Funnell et al., 2007; Kroeger et al., 2017). Hydrogen Indices of the Rakopi Formation in Taranaki Basin average 300 mg HC/g TOC (Sykes and Snowdon, 2002). The average total organic matter content (TOC) of the Rakopi Formation used in the model is 5%, based on data from the Tane-1 well (Matthews et al., 2011, Fig. 3).
Analogous to where it has been drilled by the Ariki-1 well, the Waipawa Formation is identified by a negative amplitude reflection at the top of the Paleocene interval in the seismic data (Fig. 2; Kutovaya et al., 2019). However, given the seismic resolution at this depth, it is difficult to map the thickness of the Waipawa Formation from seismic data. Proven thickness of the Waipawa Formation ranges from 10 m in the nearby Ariki-1 well (Fig. 3) to up to 40 m, where it outcrops in northern North Island (Sykes, 2008). A thicker unit may have been deposited in Cretaceous-Paleocene grabens proximal to Kora, as opposed to that drilled by wells on structural highs. To account for this uncertainty, we model scenarios using an average thickness of the Waipawa Formation of either 10 m or 30 m (Table 2). Waipawa black shale sample analysis yielded an average HI of 400 mgHC/gTOC and 10.5% TOC (Sykes, 2008). For petroleum generation modelling we use kinetics of Johansen (2005), derived from Waipawa Formation samples.


1.8
Petroleum migration modelling
For petroleum migration modelling a hybrid approach was adopted using Darcy flow migration and invasion percolation (Carruthers and van Wijngaarden, 2000; Hantschel and Kauerauf, 2009). The Darcy flow method is used for rocks with low permeabilities, whereas invasion percolation is used for more permeable rocks. The threshold permeability above which invasion percolation is used is lithology dependent and set at 100 mD at 30% porosity. In the Darcy flow method, the flow potential is calculated based on petroleum saturation and pressure differences between cells, resulting in a predicted flow rate. In the invasion percolation method, flow in permeable rocks is assumed to occur instantly within geological timescales. Flow occurs if the fluid pressure overcomes the capillary entry pressure for the target cell, depending on the in situ lithological properties and pressures in that cell. In addition to lithological properties, faults and their properties play an important role in petroleum migration (Manzocchi et al., 2010; Fisher et al., 2018; Kroeger et al., 2021). In PetroMod™, fault migration is computed using the invasion percolation method, where capillary entry pressures for the fault and for all potential outflow cells control flow through or across a fault (Hantschel and Kauerauf, 2009). We model scenarios where faults are either open to migration or have no effect on migration (Table 2). In scenarios allowing fluid migration through faults, cells surrounding the faults are refined (re-gridded to a smaller size) for better pressure calculation, whereas the faults themselves have no associated thickness. Instead, flow is controlled by the properties and pressure conditions in the in- and outflow cells adjacent to the faults rather than properties specifically assigned to the fault itself.
Four faults were mapped (Fig. 2), two on each side of the Kora volcanic edifice. All faults originated as Cretaceous graben faults and are associated with a synsedimentary change in thickness of Cretaceous‒Paleocene strata. The two faults east of the volcanic edifice were re-activated during Miocene graben formation (Giba et al., 2010). The one closer to the paleo-vent has a post-Paleocene vertical displacement of up to 200 m and offsets strata as young as Pleistocene in age.


1.9
Thermal history and magmatic heating
The PetroMod™ modelling results provide an excellent fit to DST temperature data, whereas the model predicts up to 17 °C higher temperatures than suggested by two of the corrected BHT measurements reported in Funnell et al. (2007; Fig. 4a). These differences suggest that some BHT data may have not been fully corrected for the disturbance of formation temperatures by drilling. Present-day predicted temperatures are very similar in both models a) taking into account the thermal effects of magma intrusion (scenario 1, Table 2; Fig. 4a) and b) not using magmatic heating (scenario 2, Table 2; Fig. 4b). This suggests that for the present day there are no discernible thermal effects of Miocene magmatism. Conversely, vitrinite reflectance predicted by three different kinetics (Sweeney and Burnham, 1990; Nielsen et al., 2017; Burnham, 2019), shows a marked response to magmatic heating (Fig. 4c). Since vitrinite reflectance responds to the temperature history, the model with magmatic heating provides a much better fit to measured vitrinite reflectance data (Fig. 4c and d). These results are consistent with earlier models of Kutovaya et al. (2019).
Model results suggest that conductive heat transfer from hot magma leads to a steep temperature gradient within a ∼3 km radius of influence around the central conduct and vent zone (Fig. 5
). The model predicts that a maximum extent of magmatic heating has been reached 10 kyrs after volcanic activity started. The modelled heating events are followed by rapid cooling. A thermal gradient similar to the gradient prior to magmatic activity is then re-established within 5 Myrs following the heating event (Fig. 6
a).


1.10
Petroleum generation
Model results suggest that heating related to volcanic activity had a significant impact on source rocks and resulted in rapid petroleum generation within the ∼3 km radius of influence around the central conduit and vent zone (Fig. 5‒7). Complete maturation of the Waipawa Formation near the volcanic vent is predicted to have occurred within 10 kyrs after the first modelled volcanic activity at 14 Ma (Figs. 6b and 7
a). Complete maturation of the Rakopi Formation is predicted to have occurred within 2 Myrs following the modelled start of magmatic heating (Fig. 7b). Beyond the ∼3 km radius of thermal influence of volcanism, petroleum generation was largely controlled by the depth of burial of the source rocks (Figs. 6c and d and 7c and d). Therefore, at the more deeply buried eastern side of the transect, away from the volcanic edifice, twice as much oil was generated during the Paleocene-Oligocene, before volcanic activity began (Figs. 6d and 7b and d). The rate of oil generation in the eastern part of the transect is predicted to have increased in the Middle Miocene, ∼2 Myrs before the modelled onset of volcanic activity, due to increased sedimentation rates. The start of oil and gas expulsion, however, in the model, coincides with the beginning of volcanic activity (Fig. 7). Closer to the volcanic main vent zone, expulsion resulted from magmatic heating, whereas further away, it was related to rapid burial by volcaniclastic rocks.


1.11
Migration and charge
Six different scenarios were computed (Table 2), four of which reproduced an oil accumulation with a column height of up to 42 m at the structure that was drilled by the Kora-1 well (Fig. 8
). Consistent with the accumulation encountered by the well, this accumulation is predicted to have been charged from the Waipawa Formation. This was a robust result reproduced in all models run with fault migration and secondary increase of porosity in volcanoclastic sediments. Scenarios that didn't reproduce an accumulation in the Kora-1 structure either did not consider faults as migration pathways (scenario 3, Table 2, Fig. 9
a) or assumed standard compaction for volcaniclastic rocks and no secondary increase in porosity and permeability (Fig. 9b). In all scenarios except scenario 3, faults east of the volcanic edifice acted as pathways for petroleum migration through the relatively impermeable lower Eocene and Oligocene rocks (Figs. 8 and 9). Petroleum is predicted to have then migrated upward through the Miocene succession. Waipawa oil that migrated through the easternmost of the modelled faults is predicted to have separated from the gas phase, with the oil migrating upward along volcaniclastic rocks and accumulating in the structure drilled by Kora-1. Gas is predicted to have leaked through latest Miocene to Pliocene marine mudstones covering the volcaniclastic sequence (Fig. 8). A similar migration pathway associated with a small accumulation and gas leakage to the surface is predicted for the fault closer to the volcanic edifice (Fig. 8). Waipawa oil and exsolving gas is also predicted to have leaked from the small accumulation associated with this migration pathway. In the scenario without faults, only a small proportion of expelled oil migrated through the relatively impermeable lower Eocene interval and reached the Miocene interval. West of the volcanic edifice, faults acting as migration pathways do not intersect the Eocene interval. Hence, even in the scenario with faults open to petroleum migration, little oil reached the Miocene interval and was instead trapped in the Tangaroa Formation. Conversely, models predict the potential for significant amounts of gas generated from the Rakopi Formation to have breached through the sealing lower Eocene and Oligocene intervals and accumulated in Miocene volcaniclastic rocks on the western side of the volcanic edifice (Fig. 8), although the size and location of such predicted accumulations is indicative only, due to the constraints of a 2D model.
Models predict that there is little potential for petroleum accumulation in the volcaniclastic interval before deposition of the Latest Miocene to Pleistocene marine cover sequence (Fig. 8b and c). The sealing potential of rocks overlying the volcaniclastic interval increased from the latest Miocene onwards due to increasing overburden and compaction. In the model, petroleum started to accumulate near Kora-1 when capillary entry pressure for oil in the overlying seal reached 0.18 MPa. Prior to that time, petroleum is predicted to have leaked to the surface (Fig. 8b and c). Leaking petroleum included early generated oil from the Rakopi Formation beyond the radius affected by volcanic heating as well as petroleum rapidly generated during Middle Miocene volcanic activity. Therefore, most petroleum generated during volcanic activity was not preserved. Some potential for early entrapment, however, existed in the Eocene Tangaroa Formation assuming volcanic rocks and/or the overlying Oligocene calcareous rocks acted as seals (Fig. 8c). In addition to the predicted seal capacity some predicted early accumulations are subject to the reconstruction of paleo-waterdepth.
The comparison of scenarios with and without volcanic heating (scenarios 1 and 2, Figs. 8 and 10
), supports the notion that volcanic heating reduced the oil accumulation potential in the Kora volcanic edifice due to early generation and leakage. Overall, the predicted hydrocarbon leakage amounts to up to 10 Mtons/Myr across the model (Fig. 11
), equivalent to 0.5 Mtons/km2/Myr. Additional scenarios were modelled to test the effects of lower reservoir quality of the volcaniclastic rocks (scenario 4, Table 2, Fig. 9b), variations in the thickness of the Waipawa Formation (scenario 5, Table 2), and the absence of coaly source rocks in the Rakopi Formation (scenario 6, Table 2, Fig. 9c). The results show that assuming reservoir properties consistent with normal compaction rather than an enhanced permeability due to fracturing and diagenesis (Bischoff et al., 2021) reduces predicted petroleum accumulations in these rocks and the accumulation in the Kora-1 structure was not predicted (Fig. 9b). Conversely, results for scenario 5 suggests that a thinner Waipawa Formation would still have provided sufficient charge for the accumulation in the Kora-1 structure. Assuming no source rock in the Rakopi Formation reduces the number and size of predicted accumulations around the Kora volcanic edifice (Fig. 9c), but again, demonstrates that the accumulation in the Kora-1 structure could have been charged exclusively from the Waipawa Formation. However, this scenario also predicts a much smaller amount of gas leakage into the overlying post-volcanic marine sequence.
To test whether the amplitude anomalies in the marine sequence could also be related to biogenic methane rather than thermogenic gas, we have run an additional scenario with no petroleum generation from the Rakopi Formation, but, instead, with biogenic gas generation in the marine cover sequence using the approach detailed in Kroeger et al. (2015). Similar to scenario 1 with the Rakopi Formation generating petroleum (Fig. 8a), the model with biogenic gas generation predicts focused migration of gas along faults through the marine cover sequence (Fig. 12
). Both scenarios are thus consistent with the presence of free gas, as suggested by a high amplitude anomaly in reflection seismic data (Fig. 2).



2
Discussion
Petroleum systems modelling of the Kora-1 volcanic structure approximately reproduced the small accumulation encountered in Miocene volcaniclastic rocks by the Kora-1 well (predicted column height 42 m versus 25 m observed). The associated petroleum system is summarized in Fig. 13
. Consistent with geochemical analysis of Killops et al. (1994) and Sykes et al. (2012), this accumulation is predicted to have been charged from the marine Waipawa Formation rather than from coaly source rocks in the Rakopi Formation. Nevertheless, highly reflective intervals in Cretaceous fault bounded graben structures suggest that coaly source rocks of the Rakopi Formation are present. Petroleum expulsion and migration from these source rocks in depocenters to the southeast and southwest of the Kora structure (Fig. 3) is predicted to charge additional accumulations in volcaniclastic rocks. Models suggest that in a radius of ∼3 km around the volcanic vent, rapid maturation of Waipawa and Rakopi formation source rocks has occurred during volcanic activity peaking between 14 and 12 Ma. A large proportion of petroleum generated during this time is predicted to have leaked to the surface. Leaking petroleum included early generated oil further away from the active volcanic cone that migrated towards the volcano due to doming. This is predicted to have significantly reduced the oil potential in the volcanic edifice.
Petroleum accumulation is predicted to have occurred after volcanic activity ceased and sufficient overburden was present to seal the accumulation (Fig. 13). However, lack of sufficient seal capacity of the marine mudstone overburden and extensive fracturing of volcanic and sedimentary rocks during and after volcanic activity is inferred to have prevented larger accumulations, as previously suggested by Bergmann et al. (1992) and Bischoff et al. (2021), who also considered seal as a limiting factor. Conversely, charge in the model is not predicted to have been limited by source rock volume, as models with different assumptions for the thickness of the Waipawa Formation predict the same column height accumulation. Predicted leakage through the seal above the structure drilled by Kora-1 is shown in Fig. 8a. Differences between the drilled oil column (25 m) and the predicted accumulation of petroleum at the Kora-1 well (up to 42 m) could be explained by differences between predicted and actual seal strength or in the timing of charge as containment of an earlier charge would be further limited by a poorly developed seal.
Modelling emphasized the importance of faults in charging the Kora-1 structure accumulation. The presence of faults that are open for petroleum migration is consistent with high amplitude reflections suggesting gas charge in the cover sequence that are associated with the most prominent reactivated fault east of the crest of the Kora volcano (Fig. 2). In the absence of fault migration through fine-grained Lower Eocene and Oligocene rocks, no charge of the Kora-1 structure is predicted (Fig. 9a). This is consistent with earlier modelling of Funnell et al. (2007), who found that without faults facilitating migration through the Turi Formation, petroleum generation in the relatively thin Waipawa Formation would be insufficient to charge Eocene or Miocene traps. However, charge of the Kora-1 structure is not predicted to have occurred entirely through fault migration. Instead, petroleum is predicted to have bled off the fault and to have vertically migrated through the Miocene succession rather than drained to the surface. Therefore, the permeability of the Miocene succession is also important for charge to occur. Building a basin-wide petroleum systems model requires significant simplification, and hence the complex architecture of the volcaniclastic succession with widely varying rock properties cannot be entirely reproduced. However, the results of the basin models do suggest that rather than migration occurring solely through permeable faults, permeable volcanic and epiclastic lithologies of the volcaniclastic succession are also sufficiently connected to allow petroleum migration. Conversely, and consistent with petrophysical analysis (Bischoff et al., 2021), there is no indication of the presence of effective seals within the volcaniclastic succession. Hence, sufficiently unaltered fine-grained volcaniclastic rocks that could act as seals as proposed by Wu et al. (2006) do not appear to be present or widespread enough to act as a seal in the Kora structure.
The standard approach for predicting the permeability of sedimentary rocks in basin models is through calculating reduction of porosity during burial and compaction using an exponential relationship (Athy, 1930). However, modelling shows that secondary porosity and permeability enhancement is critical for suitable reservoir presence and migration pathways to charge the petroleum accumulation in the Kora-1 structure. This is consistent with most observations of volcanic reservoirs that are typically controlled by mineral dissolution and fracturing (Magara, 2003; Wu et al., 2006; Wang et al., 2015; Wang and Chen, 2015; Jiang et al., 2017; Zheng et al., 2018; Bischoff et al., 2021). Such secondary porosity and permeability enhancement follows relationships that cannot be described by a single function.
All scenarios also predicted accumulations in the Tangaroa Formation in local highs and at the contact with modelled igneous subvolcanic intrusions (Figs. 8–10). In the absence of petrophysical information, igneous subvolcanic rocks and intrusions were generally modelled to be impermeable. Again, this is a significant simplification as these rocks can similarly be affected by mineral alteration and fracturing as volcaniclastic rocks and often form good quality reservoirs (Wang and Chen, 2015). While amplitude anomalies appear to be associated mainly with faults rather than direct leakage through the central vent area (Fig. 2), it cannot be discounted that leakage has also occurred directly through the central Kora volcanic edifice and through igneous rocks, contributing to the gas anomaly above the top of the structure. In addition, the reservoir properties of the Tangaroa Formation in the model have been solely controlled by its composition and predicted compaction. However, at Kora-1, the porosity of the Tangaroa Formation has been found to have been reduced to 10%, due to quartz and calcite cementation inferred to be related to sub-volcanic hydrothermal activity (Bergmann et al., 1992; OMV New Zealand Ltd, 2011). Nevertheless, charge of the Tangaroa Formation is consistent with shows encountered in the Kora-1 well (Arco Petroleum NZ Inc, 1988). Better reservoir properties in the Tangaroa Formation encountered in the Kora-4 well suggest that alteration of this formation is variable and that there is potential for accumulations in the Tangaroa Formation as predicted by the model. This is supported by the thermal model calibration that is consistent with predominantly conductive heating and doesn't require hydrothermal heating. Hydrothermal activity may have influenced a larger area than the radius of conductive heating predicted by the model and thus affected petroleum generation, migration and accumulation in ways not accounted for in this study. Similarly, the poorly constrained effects of a deeper intrusion were not considered in the model. Such an intrusion could have increased thermal gradients over a wider area around the Kora edifice and could have resulted in more petroleum generation and leakage during magmatic activity.
Whilst, consistent with geochemical data, the accumulation in the Kora-1 structure is predicted to have been charged almost exclusively by Waipawa oil, modelling shows that presence of a Rakopi Formation source rock is critical for charging additional accumulations in volcanosedimentary rocks on the western side of the Kora volcanic structure. The predicted potential for oil and gas expulsion from the Rakopi Formation is a significant result for petroleum prospectivity in northern Taranaki Basin, where so far, no significant discoveries related to petroleum generation from Late Cretaceous source rocks have been made (Sykes et al., 2012), despite the widespread mapped occurrence of the interval (Arnot and Bland, 2016, Fig. 3). However, as all encountered fluids in Miocene rocks have been typed to the Waipawa Formation (Killops et al., 1994; Sykes et al., 2012), the only possible evidence for petroleum generation from the Rakopi Formation around the Kora volcanic structure remains to be the widespread occurrence of seismic reflection anomalies in the marine cover sequence that are likely related to gas (Fig. 2). Modelling suggests that such gas accumulations are unlikely to be linked to gas migrated from the Waipawa Formation alone, due to the smaller quantity of gas expelled. However, modelling is also consistent with a possible biogenic origin of the gas. A third possibility is that the gas could be CO2, either related to exsolution from the aqueous phase after volcanic activity and cooling of magma (Guilbert and Park, 1986) or derived from coaly source rocks heated by intrusions (Schmidt and McDonald, 1979; Surdam et al., 1984; Higgs et al., 2021). A volcanic source is questionable due to the long inactivity of the magmatic system. Further evidence could lie in the depth of amplitude anomalies since the bulk of any pure CO2 will be in a supercritical phase below a depth of 800 m (Law and Bachu, 1996), and hence less likely to cause amplitude anomalies. However, while the most pronounced likely gas related anomalies in the marine cover sequence are shallower than 800 m, some inverse polarity high amplitude reflections are observed at greater depth (Fig. 2).
Over time, significant amounts of oil and gas are predicted to have leaked to the surface. Leaking petroleum has largely been generated from the Rakopi Formation in scenarios assuming presence of the source rock. Three main factors can be identified that drove leakage of petroleum: 1) early petroleum generation related to volcanic activity before deposition of regional seals, 2) the likelihood of connected permeability across the volcanic structure and effective migration to the surface, 3) doming related to magmatic activity, resulting in the migration and leakage of petroleum generated early beyond the radius of thermal heating through the volcanic edifice. These results significantly impact prospectivity, due to the volume of petroleum lost to the system. Specifically, the potential for discovering oil is significantly reduced due to the leakage of early generated oil. Widespread leakage through the seal is consistent with the common occurrence of oil residues in fractures in the degradational sandstones overlying the volcano-sedimentary succession (Bischoff et al., 2021).
Modelling predicts that petroleum has leaked over geological time at a rate of 0.5 Mtons of hydrocarbons/km2/Myr. The ∼100 km2 Kora volcanic system could thus have emitted 50 Mtons of gas, with a large proportion of Methane per Million years, not taking into account any release of igneous CO2 directly sourced from the magmatic system. As Kora was only one of many Miocene volcanoes in Zealandia, many of which are located in petroliferous basins (Bischoff et al., 2020), the overall contribution to atmospheric methane and CO2 and impact on the carbon cycle could have been significant over geological time scales. On a global scale, carbon isotope perturbations, for instance at the onset of the Miocene Climate optimum have been attributed to extensive volcanism (Hodell and Woodruff, 1994; Holbourn et al., 2015). Our results highlight the potential for significant greenhouse gas emissions from volcanism in sedimentary basins with petroleum source rocks, similar to the effect of sill emplacement in the North Atlantic (Dickens, 2004; Svensen et al., 2004). As volcanism varied globally due to changes in plate convergence, this could have been a potential climate driver (Reagan et al., 2013).
In summary, modelling suggests that at the Kora volcanic edifice there is likely potential for further undiscovered accumulations. This potential depends to a large extent on petroleum generation from the Rakopi Formation and migration of petroleum from Cretaceous rift grabens situated to the southwest and southeast of Kora (Fig. 3). Accumulations are likely to be gas dominated, due to the early leakage of oil. Modelling results support the presence of extensive secondary porosity and permeability proposed for the Kora-1 structure (Bischoff et al., 2021) that has been documented in volcanic petroleum systems elsewhere (Wu et al., 2006; Wang et al., 2015; Wang and Chen, 2015; Zheng et al., 2018). Limiting factors may be fault leakage or the complex compartmentalization of reservoirs. However, the key limiting factor at Kora was found to be an insufficient seal. For these reasons, when looking at the petroleum potential of volcanic edifices, the size of the structure is likely deceiving in terms of its actual petroleum potential. As seal strength is likely to control the size of potential accumulations, the properties of the cover rock and the depth of burial, and hence also the age of the system are important. Similarly the importance of the sealing potential of marine sedimentary rocks overlying Neogene volcanics and its dependence on overburden has been demonstrated for several sites onshore Japan (Magara, 2003). These results are consistent with a dominance of small gas accumulations in relatively shallow (400–2000 m) volcanic reservoirs of relatively young (Cenozoic and Late Cretaceous) age worldwide (Feng, 2008). Conversely, reservoirs sealed by lacustrine mudstones in the in the Songliao Basin in northeast China, where some of the largest gas accumulations in volcanic rocks have been found, are buried to 2800–4500 m (Feng, 2008). Analysis of the oldest marine cover sediment at Kora suggests that a well cemented shallow marine rock was deposited during the early degradational phase of the volcanic edifice (Bischoff et al., 2021). In the case of the Kora structure, this sediment was also extensively fractured and hence has low sealing potential. Bischoff et al. (2021) propose that fracturing of this rock is due to Late Miocene tectonism related to the evolution of the Northern Graben system in Taranaki Basin (King and Thrasher, 1996). Hence, fracturing of these rocks may be specific to the structural evolution and late tectonism in Taranaki Basin. There are examples in China, often in areas with little post-magmatic tectonism, where rocks formed during the weathering and degradation stage have been found to be both reservoirs and effective seals (Zou et al., 2012, 2014). This underlines that understanding the sedimentary and tectonic history of the basin after volcanic activity ceased is critical for assessing the petroleum potential of buried volcanoes.


3
Conclusions
We used the Miocene Kora stratovolcano in offshore northwestern New Zealand as an example to analyse factors controlling the petroleum potential and fluid flow in buried volcanic edifices. The results of a series of 2D basin modelling scenarios testing the influence of magmatic heating on source rock maturation, rock property distribution and fault migration indicate that multiple factors are critical for the accumulation of petroleum in buried stratovolcano edifices. These are:

1)
Consistent with petrophysical studies, modelling suggests that extensive fracturing and secondary porosity exist around volcanic edifices, resulting in connected permeability enabling fluid migration and enhancing reservoir potential despite the heterogeneity in volcanic and associated epiclastic rocks.


2)
Faults play an important role in migration through impermeable strata but also facilitate leakage to the surface.


3)
The potential for petroleum accumulation is limited by seal strength, which is controlled by lithology, thickness and timing of deposition of a sedimentary cover sequence above the volcanic edifice.


4)
The deposition of a well-cemented shallow marine degradational layer deposited when volcanic activity ceased can be critical for seal formation. The properties of such a deposit depend on the late tectonic and burial history, where in the case of the Kora volcano, Late Miocene extension has likely caused pervasive fracturing of these rocks and significantly reduced seal potential.


5)
Petroleum expulsion from source rocks further away from the volcano and unaffected by magmatic heating that allows petroleum to migrate into the volcanic structure after seal formation is important for charging accumulations.



These results emphasize that the geological setting and tectonic and burial history after volcanic activity is critical for the petroleum potential and fluid storage capacity of buried volcanic edifices. The predicted leakage of greenhouse gases from the Kora system associated with widespread Miocene volcanism in petroliferous basins on the Zealandia continent supports the notion that, on a global scale, greenhouse gas emission related to volcanism was significant in the Miocene and modified earth's climate over geological time scales.

1
Introduction
The presence of a thermally mature and viable source rock unit is one of the key risk factors in oil and gas exploration (White, 1993; Katz, 2005). Several factors may influence the development of a potential source rock unit, including primary organic production, preservation environment, and sedimentation rate (Pedersen and Calvert, 1990; Arthur et al., 1994; Calvert et al., 1996; Bohacs et al., 2005; Katz, 2005). In addition, the tectonic setting of a basin may represent an important first-order control on processes such as accommodation development (e.g. subsidence and burial) and water mass circulation that are vital for source rock development (Demaison et al., 1983; Gawthorpe et al., 2000). Across the Norwegian Continental Shelf (NCS), Upper Jurassic organic-rich shales have traditionally been given the most attention, as these represent the main source rock unit charging most of the largest producing oil and gas fields (Demaison et al., 1983; Cooper et al., 1984; Isaksen et al., 2001; Marín et al., 2020). This has left alternative source rock units to be considered as insignificant or even neglected (Ohm et al., 2008). This is also the case for the Barents Shelf, the northernmost and least explored hydrocarbon province of the NCS. Across large parts of the NCS, the widely distributed Upper Jurassic source rock unit was generally deposited during a period characterized by active faulting forming structurally restricted basins that were ideal sites for the accumulation and preservation of organic matter (e.g. Faleide et al., 1984; Leith et al., 1993; Jongepier et al., 1996; Langrock et al., 2003; Marín et al., 2020). However, despite its extensive distribution across the SW Barents Shelf, the traditional Upper Jurassic source rock unit only appears to be mature in a narrow belt along the western margin of the Hammerfest Basin and on the margins of the Loppa High (Dore, 1995; Marín et al., 2020). In the deeper marginal basins further to the west, the Upper Jurassic source rock unit has been buried very deeply and is over-mature (Ohm et al., 2008). Documenting the presence of alternative source rock units at stratigraphic shallower intervals is, therefore, crucial for exploration success in these frontier areas.
Such alternative source rock units may occur in the Lower Cretaceous and Paleogene successions (Leith et al., 1993; Øygard and Olsen, 2002; Seldal, 2005; Lerch et al., 2017; Sattar et al., 2017). Several exploration wells have confirmed the presence of Lower Cretaceous source rock units in the Fingerdjupet Subbasin (e.g. 7321/9–1) and in the western part of the Hammerfest Basin (e.g. 7120/6-3 S) (NPD Factpages, 2021). Moreover, some petroleum discoveries have previously been linked to Lower Cretaceous source rocks by biomarkers (e.g. wells 7120/10–1, 7120/1–2, 7120/2-3 S, 6706/12–2, 6305/8–1, and 6405/7) (Lerch et al., 2017; NPD Factpages, 2021), and on the Mid-Norwegian Shelf are several oil discoveries identified as sourced by Cretaceous source rocks (Matapour and Karlsen, 2017). A regionally extensive, gas condensate-prone source rock unit of early Aptian age have been identified onshore Svalbard at the northwestern corner of the Barents Shelf (Midtkandal et al., 2016; Grundvåg et al., 2019). In addition, oil stains discovered in sandstones onshore northeastern Greenland indicate the presence of a Cretaceous-age source rock (Bojesen-Koefoed et al., 2020). However, there are large uncertainties related to the presence, stratigraphic position, and lateral distribution of Lower Cretaceous source rock units offshore, particularly in the deep basins along the western shelf margin. The regional significance of Lower Cretaceous source rocks is, therefore, still largely unclear (Dore, 1995; Mann et al., 2002; Øygard and Olsen, 2002; Seldal, 2005; Lerch et al., 2017). Thus, a detailed investigation of organic-rich units exhibiting source rock potential within the Lower Cretaceous succession seems essential in developing new play models and reducing exploration risk in the western frontier areas of the Barents Shelf.
By combining high-resolution regional 2D seismic data, well logs, and a digitalized Rock-Eval database, this study documents the lateral and stratigraphic distribution and variability of potential source rock units within the Lower Cretaceous succession on the southwestern Barents Shelf (Fig. 1
). In particular, this study applies traditional source rock evaluation methods (sensu Peters and Cassa, 1994) to establish the potential and quality of the recognized potential source rock units in the shallow basins located on the interior platform part of the shelf (e.g. the Fingerdjupet Subbasin and Hammerfest Basin). This analysis will further aid in mapping the lateral and stratigraphic distribution of potential source rock units in the deeper marginal basins (e.g. the Tromsø and Bjørnøya basins). Finally, various factors that controlled the development and distribution of the investigated organic-rich intervals, such as the tectono-sedimentary evolution of the various basins, are evaluated and discussed.


2
Geological framework

2.1
Structural setting
The Barents Shelf is an epicontinental platform situated between the Norwegian mainland in the south, the Svalbard archipelago and Franz Josef Land to the north, and Novaya Zemlya to the east/southeast (Fig. 1). Following the Caledonian orogeny in the Late Silurian – Early Devonian, the shelf has undergone multiple phases of extension and subordinate compression, which have resulted in a complex pattern of fault-bounded basins and highs, as well as platform areas and smaller inversion-related structures (Faleide et al., 1984, 1993a, 1993b, 2008; Riis et al., 2014). The main extensional, basin-forming phases occurred during i) the Late Devonian associated with the collapse of the Caledonian orogenic belt, ii) the Late Carboniferous, iii) the Late Permian – Early Triassic, iv) the Late Jurassic – Early Cretaceous, and v) finally during the complete opening of the NE Atlantic rift system during the Late Cretaceous – Early Paleogene (Faleide et al., 2008, 2015).
The most important basins for this study include: 1) the Fingerdjupet Subbasin; 2) the Bjørnøya Basin; 3) Hammerfest Basin; and 4) the Tromsø Basin (Fig. 1). In general, the evolution of these basins is related to the Late Jurassic – Early Cretaceous extensional event. A brief outline of their structural development is given below.

2.1.1
Fingerdjupet Subbasin
The Fingerdjupet Subbasin is considered to be the shallow northeastern extension of the Bjørnøya Basin. Its southern and western boundaries are defined by the Leirdjupet Fault Complex (LFC) (Gabrielsen et al., 1990; Faleide et al., 1993a), whereas the Bjarmeland Platform and the Loppa High defines its eastern and southeastern boundaries (Gabrielsen et al., 1990, Fig. 1). The Fingerdjupet Subbasin is characterized by a horst and graben configuration, with a series of faults that developed during Late Jurassic extension and local reactivation during the Early Cretaceous (Faleide et al., 1993b). This includes the Randi Fault Set (RFS), situated in the eastern transition to the Bjarmeland Platform (Serck et al., 2017). Furthermore, an Aptian extensional event is well documented in the Fingerdjupet Subbasin (Faleide et al., 1993a; Clark et al., 2014; Blaich et al., 2017; Serck et al., 2017). This fault activity initiated the formation of localized wedges and contributed to the uplift of the northern parts of Loppa High (Indrevær et al., 2017; Marín et al., 2017). Because of Cenozoic uplift and erosion (Henriksen et al., 2011; Lasabuda et al., 2018, 2021) only the lowermost part of the Lower Cretaceous succession is preserved in the basin.


2.1.2
Bjørnøya Basin
The NE–SW-oriented Bjørnøya Basin is bounded by the LFC to the east, by the Bjørnøyrenna Fault Complex (BFC) to the southeast, and by the faulted margin of the Stappen High to the northwest (Fig. 1), cf. Gabrielsen et al. (1990). Structuring of the Bjørnøya Basin is also attributed to the Late Jurassic – Early Cretaceous extensional event (Faleide et al., 1993a, 1993b). Consequently, most of the basin infill is of Early Cretaceous age (Gabrielsen et al., 1990; Faleide et al., 1993a). The basin was affected by faulting and local inversion in association with the BFC and uplift of the Stappen High during the Late Cretaceous and Paleogene (Faleide et al., 1993a).


2.1.3
Hammerfest Basin
The Hammerfest Basin is an elongated ENE – WSW oriented basin, located south of the Loppa High (Fig. 1). The Ringvassøy-Loppa Fault Complex (RLFC) separates it from the deeper Tromsø Basin to the west, while the Asterias Fault complex (AFC) separates it from the Loppa High (Gabrielsen et al., 1990). Its southern border is defined by the Troms-Finnmark Fault Complex (TFFC), which separates the basin from the Finnmark Platform (Gabrielsen et al., 1990). Structuring of the Hammerfest Basin is mainly attributed to extension in Triassic and Late Jurassic to Early Cretaceous times (Berglund et al., 1986; Gabrielsen et al., 1990; Faleide et al., 1993a). Local compression has also been documented (Sund, 1984; Gabrielsen et al., 1997; Indrevær et al., 2017). Uplift and doming along the central basin axis started in the Middle Jurassic (Berglund et al., 1986) and extended into the Early Cretaceous (Berglund et al., 1986; Faleide et al., 1993a). Consequently, new depocenters formed along the boundaries of the Hammerfest Basin (Marín et al., 2017). The uplift ceased in the early Barremian (Faleide et al., 1993a), leaving most of the Barremian – Aptian succession confined within the faulted boundaries of the basin (Marín et al., 2017, 2018b).


2.1.4
Tromsø Basin
The Tromsø Basin is an NNE – SSW-oriented basin that transitions southwards into the Harstad Basin, eventually terminating against the TFFC (Fig. 1). The BFC and the Veslemøy High define its northern boundary, separating it from the Bjørnøya Basin. The RLFC delineates the eastern boundary towards the Hammerfest Basin, while the Senja Ridge marks its western boundary (Gabrielsen et al., 1990). As the North Atlantic rift system advanced northward during the Middle Jurassic – Early Cretaceous, deep basins formed along the southwestern Barents Shelf margin (Faleide et al., 1993a, 1993b). The Early Cretaceous extensional event in the Tromsø Basin was focused along the NE-SW trending RLFC and the BFC. Consequently, the Tromsø Basin experienced rapid subsidence, creating immense accommodation space for Cretaceous sediments, preserved as an up to ca. 8 km thick succession (Rønnevik et al., 1982; Gabrielsen et al., 1990; Faleide et al., 1993a, 2008; Clark et al., 2014; Indrevær et al., 2017; Kairanov et al., 2021). A total of three Early Cretaceous extensional phases have been documented for the Tromsø Basin (Berriasian – Valanginian, Hauterivian – Barremian and Aptian – Albian) (Faleide et al., 1993a; Kairanov et al., 2021). In addition, Late Palaeozoic salt deposits were mobilized by rapid subsidence and differential loading during Albian times, triggering diapirism in the central parts of the basin (Kairanov et al., 2021).



2.2
Lower Cretaceous stratigraphy and depositional systems
The Lower Cretaceous succession on the Barents Shelf is divided into the Knurr (Berriasian – Early Barremian), Klippfisk (Late Berriasian – Hauterivian), Kolje (Barremian – Early Aptian) and Kolmule (Aptian – Cenomanian) Formations (Fig. 2
), collectively assigned to the Adventdalen Group (Parker, 1967; Dalland et al., 1988). Because there are some age-related uncertainties in correlating these units across the various basins, the Lower Cretaceous succession was recently subdivided into seven genetic sequences (S0 – S6; Fig. 2) bounded by regionally extensive flooding surfaces (Marín et al., 2017). Sequences S0 and S1 corresponds to the Knurr and Klippfisk formations, whereas sequence S2 correspond roughly to the Kolje Formation, and sequences S3 to S6 represents the Kolmule Formation (Marín et al., 2017, Fig. 2).
On the SW Barents Shelf, the Lower Cretaceous succession was generally deposited in open marine shelf environments, affected by periods of restricted bottom circulation (Dalland et al., 1988). The dominant lithology of the succession is grey-brown mudstones with interbeds of siltstone, limestone, and local sandstones (e.g. Worsley et al., 1988; Bugge et al., 2002; Seldal, 2005). The up to 285 m thick (as measured in well 7120/12–1) mudstone-dominated Knurr Formation (Valanginian–early Barremian), and the laterally equivalent carbonate-dominated Klippfisk Formation (Valanginian–Hauterivian) on the eastern platform areas constitute the lowermost part of the Lower Cretaceous succession (Dalland et al., 1988; Smelror et al., 1998). These are both condensed units containing multiple stratigraphic gaps (Smelror et al., 2009). Sandstone units emplaced by gravity-flow process occur locally near structural highs (Seldal, 2005; Sattar et al., 2017; Marín et al., 2018a).
The up to 437 m thick (as measured in well 7119/12–1) mudstone-dominated Kolje Formation (Barremian – earliest Aptian) was deposited in a shelf setting under generally well-oxygenated, open marine conditions (Dalland et al., 1988). A large-scale delta system prograding from the NW, reached the Fingerdjupet Subbasin in Barremian – Aptian times, as evident by the presence of several clinoform-bearing sequences in the upper part of the Barremian succession (Grundvåg et al., 2017; Marín et al., 2017; Midtkandal et al., 2019). A regionally extensive flooding surface, which caps the clinoforms, separates the Kolje Formation from the overlying Kolmule Formation (Grundvåg et al., 2017; Serck et al., 2017; Marín et al., 2018b).
The up to 950 m thick (as measured in well 7119/12–1) mudstone-rich and sandstone-bearing Kolmule Formation (Aptian–Middle Cenomanian) was deposited in response to significant uplift of the northeastern Barents Shelf, particularly during the Albian. Large amounts of sediments were shed off uplifted terranes and transported towards the rapidly subsiding basins along the southwestern shelf margin, such as the Harstad, Tromsø and Bjørnøya basins (Faleide et al., 1993a, 1993b; Smelror et al., 2009). Consequently, a large delta system prograded from the E to NE onto the SW Barents Shelf in the Aptian – Cenomanian (Grundvåg et al., 2017; Marín et al., 2017; Midtkandal et al., 2019). At these times, the shelf was generally characterized by well-oxygenated, open marine conditions (Smelror et al., 2009).



3
Data and methods

3.1
Seismic data
This study includes several high-resolution regional 2D seismic surveys (NBR, 2006–2012). The different orientation and spacing (1–8 km) of the 2D lines make up a grid that spans the study area, thus forming a regional pseudo 3D-grid. The acquisition of these surveys took place over a period of several years, resulting in varying quality between the surveys. In general, frequencies are in the range of 10–50 Hz, while the polarity convention for the dataset is zero-phase normal polarity, following the nomenclature of Sheriff (2002). The description of reflection configurations and seismic geometries follow the terminology established by Mitchum et al. (1977).
Confidence of the seismic interpretations within the deeper basins is strongly affected by a decreasing seismic quality with depth. In addition, no well data were available for either the central parts of the Tromsø or the Bjørnøya basins.

3.1.1
Seismic response to organic-rich intervals and mapping of potential source rock units
Mudrocks with total organic carbon (TOC) contents >3 – 4% typically have significantly lower acoustic impedance and higher intrinsic anisotropy than mudrocks with lower amounts of organic content. The general density of kerogen is typical in the range of 1.1–1.4 g/cm3, while mudrocks generally have a density of 2.7 g/cm3 (Løseth et al., 2011; Rider and Kennedy, 2011). Organic matter will, therefore, influence the seismic response trough compressional velocity (Vp), shear velocity (Vs), bulk density, anisotropy, and attenuation (Løseth et al., 2011). A potential source rock unit may thus result in a high amplitude reflection characterized by a negative top and a positive base (Løseth et al., 2011). Furthermore, the acoustic impedance contrast is relatively stable down to a depth of c. 4500 m and decreases nonlinearly with increasing TOC content (Løseth et al., 2011). This has clear implications for the Lower Cretaceous succession, which is buried at depths down to 5–7 s two-way-travel time, in the deep Bjørnøya and Tromsø basins (Gabrielsen et al., 1990; Kairanov et al., 2021).
The seismic mapping thus specifically targets the top of potential source rock units as these are displayed as negative high-amplitude anomalies in the data. Biostratigraphic age determination of the mapped reflectors are guided by well tops from the publicly available database of the Norwegian Petroleum Directorate (NPD Factpages, 2021) and from in-house data provided by Wintershall-Dea Norway. In the deep Tromsø and Bjørnøya basins, well 7219/8-1 S is a key reference point in providing age-control of the Lower Cretaceous succession. In most cases, the targeted reflectors seem to correspond to regionally extensive maximum flooding surfaces documented by previous studies (e.g. Marín et al., 2017). Thus, for regional stratigraphic context, the genetic sequence subdivision of Marín et al. (2017, 2018a, 2018b), and partly that of Serck et al. (2017), is used for guidance in the Hammerfest Basin and Fingerdjupet Subbasin, respectively (with some minor modifications). In the Bjørnøya Basin, the stratigraphic subdivision builds largely on that of the Fingerdjupet Subbasin by correlating the seismic horizons across the LFC and TFC (Fig. 1). In the Tromsø Basin, the stratigraphic framework used in this study, builds largely on the recent work of Kairanov et al. (2021), and by linking it to the stratigraphic framework established by Marín et al. (2017) for the Hammerfest Basin.
To investigate lateral variability and distribution of potential source rock units, average negative amplitude maps have been generated for two of the high-amplitude reflectors following the workflow of Løseth et al. (2011). The negative amplitude map is not very reliable in the deep basins because of deteriorating seismic quality and reflector dimming, making a lateral correlation from the shallow basins a difficult and time-consuming task. Consequently, amplitude maps have only been generated for two of the mapped reflectors. The generation of the amplitude map uses a search window of 5 ms above and 20 ms below the interpretation of the reflector.



3.2
Well data
Seventeen exploration wells have been selected and investigated for this study (Fig. 1 and Table 1
). All the wells have an established time-depth relationship trough calibration of check shots. Most of the wells exhibit a common suite of wireline-logs including gamma ray (GR), sonic (AC/DT), density (DEN), and deep resistivity (RDEP). Wireline logs are generally regarded to be a good supplement to seismic data when evaluating the presence of potential source rock units, Thus, to confirm the presence of potential source rock units mapped in the seismic data, wireline log signals are integrated with digitalized TOC logs derived from the Rock-Eval data. The thicknesses of the potential source rock units are estimated from the wireline data and subsequently, TOC samples within the interval, or from stratigraphically nearby intervals, are evaluated (Table 1). The typical wireline response to organic rich units is briefly outlined below.

3.2.1
Wireline responses to organic-rich units

3.2.1.1
Gamma ray log (GR)
Organic-rich mudrocks commonly show high GR values because of elevated concentrations of uranium. However, this is not always the case as uranium can be a highly mobile element under the right conditions (Bowker and Grace, 2010; Helleren et al., 2020). In addition, the GR-signal may be subject to various interference from the well casing.


3.2.1.2
Sonic log (AC/DT)
The presence of organic matter in mudrocks will lower the sonic travel time (Rider and Kennedy, 2011). This response is evidently more apparent in mature source rocks. However, using the sonic log independently to identify organic rich intervals is problematic, because it is impossible to separate low sonic values caused by the presence of organic matter from low sonic values caused by porosity changes (Rider and Kennedy, 2011).


3.2.1.3
Resistivity log (RDEP)
The resistivity logs response to a source rock depends on the maturity of the organic matter (Rider and Kennedy, 2011). In immature organic matter, the response will be small due to high conductivity. In mature source rocks where, free petroleum are present in voids and fractures, the resistivity will increase significantly (Rider and Kennedy, 2011).


3.2.1.4
Density log (DEN)
Mudrocks containing low amounts of organic matter have a higher density matrix (2.67 – 2.72 g/cm3) compared to pure organic matter (1.1 – 1.2 g/cm3). The density log will consequently read lower values in organic rich mudrocks (Rider and Kennedy, 2011). The presence of organic matter thus has a distinct effect on the overall mudrock density, which also shifts the acoustic impedance in the seismic data towards negative amplitudes (Løseth et al., 2011).




3.3
Rock-Eval data
In order to establish the richness, type, and thermal maturity of the source rock units identified in the seismic and wireline data, traditional source rock evaluation following the principles of Espitalié et al. (1977), Peters (1986) and Peters and Cassa (1994) are used. The Rock-Eval data presented here are based on samples derived from either sidewall cores or drill cuttings from the 17 wells. The sample spacing varies between each well (ranging from samples collected every 2–100 m; see Table 1 for sampling interval details), which consequently makes it difficult to achieve a good representation of thin source rock units occurring between the sampled intervals. In these cases, the nearest samples to the interval have been used where applicable. To establish the thermal maturity of the potential source rock units, emphasis has been given to Tmax values as these are numerous throughout the dataset, while the scarce vitrinite reflectance (Ro) data supplement the interpretation when applicable.
The Rock-Eval database has been digitalized and implemented into Petrel for each corresponding well. This makes it possible for a direct correlation between the source rock reflections and the Rock-Eval data at any of the well locations. The complete Rock-Eval database, including TOC content, is given in the online supplementary file SF1.



4
Results

4.1
Seismic sequences and bounding surfaces
Seven genetic sequences (S0 – S6) and their bounding surfaces (i.e., the BCU, iuH, iB, ilA, ilAl, iuAl, IuCn reflectors of this study, see detailed descriptions below) are recognized within the Lower Cretaceous succession in the study area (Figs. 3 and 4

), conforming to the well-established sequence stratigraphic framework of Marín et al. (2017, 2018a, 2018b). Thus, apart from the Base Cretaceous Unconformity (BCU), which defines the base of the Lower Cretaceous succession, the sequence-bounding surfaces represent regionally extensive maximum flooding surfaces that may be correlated from the Hammerfest Basin and the Fingerdjupet Subbasin westward into the Tromsø and Bjørnøya basins (Figs. 3 and 4; Marín et al., 2017). Bellow follows a seismic description of the genetic sequences and their bounding surfaces.

4.1.1
Sequence 0 (Berriasian – Hauterivian)
Sequence 0 is bounded at the base by the regionally extensive BCU, and atop by the intra upper Hauterivian reflector (iuH). The BCU appears as a high amplitude reflector. The iuH reflector has a negative amplitude with variable magnitude and continuity.
