1
Introduction
The Greater Caucasus mountain range, situated between the Black Sea and the Caspian Sea, is an outstanding landmark at the crossroads between Asia and Europe (Fig. 1
). The Caucasus forms an orogenic system whose geologic structure and position in the Alpine-Himalayan belt is determined by the still converging Eurasian and Arabian lithospheric plates (Allen et al., 2004; Gamkrelidze, 1986; Jackson, 1992; McClusky et al., 2000; Tan and Taymaz, 2006; Vernant et al., 2004). During the Mesozoic-Early Cenozoic times, the region belonged to the now vanished Neotethys-Eurasia ocean-continent convergence zone (Adamia et al., 2011; Adamia and Zakariadze, 2011). It has undergone, since the Late Triassic, a history of regional extension and compression summarized as the Cimmerian (Eo-, Meso-, Neo-) and Alpine stages (Nikishin et al., 2001; Vincent et al., 2011). The Greater Caucasus mountain range arises from the inversion, during the Alpine stage, from the former Greater Caucasus Basin. This intracontinental rift basin evolved in a back-arc rift setting linked to north-directed subduction under the Lesser Caucasus to the south (Sosson et al., 2016). The Mountain range develops an overall doubly verging orogenic wedge, with important along strike changes in geometry from west to east. The main transport direction is to the South (Dotduyev, 1986), towards the pro-wedge domain of the orogenic wedge, as opposed to the north-directed thrusts of the retro-wedge (Forte et al., 2014a; Mosar et al., 2010; Sosson et al., 2016).
The objective of our paper is to discuss the present-day structural setting along a crosg section through the whole Greater Caucasus, and link the different tectonic zones to their original paleotectonic setting. We thus introduce a new paleotectonic reconstruction of the Greater Caucasus Basin. Hereafter, we present the results from field investigations along the Georgian Military Road in Eastern Georgia and Russai, and adjoining valleys, between Tbilissi and Vladikavkaz (Fig. 2
), and summarize earlier works that to present the general tectonic structure of this part of the Central Greater Caucasus (GC). Collecting new structural data such bedding dips, cleavage orientation, fold axis trend and axial surfaces, as well as faults and thus detailing and densifying existing map data, made it possible to produce a new set of geological maps (appendixes) and to extract kinematic information. Fieldwork was conducted in the frame of sevral projects over a period of several years between 2010 and 2018.
In the light of an inferred intracontinental and doubly verging character of the GC orogen (Mosar et al., 2010), the delimited and described tectonic units are restored into a pre-collisional (Early Cenozoic) rift setting, from which the present-day structure of the Caucasus region and more specifically the Greater Caucasus is inherited.


2
Regional geology and geodynamics of the Caucasus
The highest mountain range in the Caucasus region, the Geater Caucasus (GC), is a doubly verging fold-and-thrust belt (FTB), which originated from the tectonic inversion of a Mesozoic-Early Cenozoic intracontinental rift, the GC Basin, that bordered the Scythian Platform (southern part of the East European/Russian Platform) to the south (Adamia and Zakariadze, 2011; Gobarenko et al., 2015; Mosar et al., 2010; Saintot et al., 2006; Vincent et al., 2016; Yilmaz et al., 2014) (Fig. 1). Prior to the Arabia-Eurasia collision, this deep marine basin was located to the north of the active margin of the continental Eurasian plate in a supra-subduction setting with respect to the northward-directed subduction of the Neotethys Ocean (Adamia et al., 1977, 2011; Golonka, 2004; Nikishin et al., 2001; Philip et al., 1989; Sosson et al., 2016; Zonenshain and LePichon, 1986). The GC Basin developed following the Late Triassic accretion of the Cimmerian Terranes to Eurasia and the initiation of the Neotethys subduction at the southern edge of the Eurasian plate (Eo-Cimmerian event) (Golonka, 2004; Nikishin et al., 2001; Stampfli et al., 2013). Lower Jurassic back-arc extension separated the Transcaucasian-Lesser Caucasus (South Caucasus) domains from the Scythian Platform (North Caucasus), thus opening the GC rift-basin (Golonka, 2004; Khain, 2007). Rift activity encompassed the Middle Jurassic period and intensely thinned the continental crust underlying the basin (Adamia et al., 1977, 2011; Adamia and Zakariadze, 2011; Khain, 2007; Saintot et al., 2006; Vincent et al., 2016). This hyperextension of the continental crust is recorded in the present axial part of the GC belt by a mid-ocean ridge basalt-like (MORB) magmatism that occurred during the Lower-Middle Jurassic in the GC Basin axis (Panov and Lomize, 2007; Saintot et al., 2006; Vincent et al., 2016). A regionally observed Bathonian unconformity (Mid-Cimmerian event) marked the onset of the post-rift thermally subsiding basin development (Saintot et al., 2006; Vincent et al., 2016).
Marine sedimentation within the GC Basin began in the Sinemurian (in places Late Hettangian (Adamia et al., 2011; Khain, 2007) and included the Jurassic, Cretaceous, and Early Paleogene (Dotduyev, 1986; Adamia et al., 2011; Nikishin et al., 2001; Saintot et al., 2006; Vincent et al., 2016; Blackbourn et al., 2021). Terrigenous and hemipelagic deposits, mainly shales, characterized the pre-Callovian basin infill (Adamia et al., 1977; Saintot et al., 2006; Yakovlev, 2012), whereas thick flysch-like units composed of siliciclastic and carbonate turbidite sequences define the Upper Jurassic to Late Eocene times (Nikishin et al., 2010; Saintot et al., 2006; Yakovlev, 2012). In total, the thickness of the basin infill exceeds 10 km (Adamia et al., 2011).
The Late Eocene-Oligocene is considered as the period of beginning of the Alpine orogenic stage (Mosar, 2010; Saintot et al., 2006; Saintot and Angelier, 2002; Sosson et al., 2016; Trifonov and Sokolov, 2014; Vincent et al., 2017; Yakovlev, 2012) i.e. the incipient tectonic inversion of the GC Basin (Nikishin et al., 2010). The closure of the Neotethys and the initiation of the Arabia-Eurasia continent-continent collision in the Late Eocene-Oligocene (e.g. at 36 Ma (Ballato et al., 2011), 35 Ma (Allen and Armstrong, 2008), 35-30 Ma (Jolivet and Faccenna, 2000), or 30-25 Ma (Neill et al., 2015) rapidly transferred the compression northwards and induced the tectonic inversion and incipient uplift of the GC (Vincent et al., 2007, 2016). The Arabia-Eurasia collision and the onset of the orogenic process in the GC is marked in the Caucasus region first by the regional deposition of the mud-prone, gypsiferous, and organic-rich Maykop formation (Oligocene-Lower Miocene) in isolated euxinic basins of the eastern Paratethys (Adamia et al., 2011; Adamia and Zakariadze, 2011; Allen and Armstrong, 2008; Vincent et al., 2016), and then by the formation of the foredeeps adjacent to the GC (Adamia et al., 2011; Almendinger et al., 2011; Ershov et al., 1999, 2003; Khlebnikova et al., 2014; Mikhailov et al., 1999; Nikishin et al., 2010; Timoshkina et al., 2010). Furthermore, on both sides of the GC, Oligocene (Maykop) and younger sediments display divergent paleocurrents, away from the axis of the growing orogenic range (Vincent et al., 2007, 2016) and comprise erosional material derived from the crystalline core of the GC and from inverted Jurassic to Eocene basin deposits, thus indicating a subaerial sediment source since Oligocene (Khlebnikova et al., 2014; Vincent et al., 2016).
We divide the present Caucasus region into five large-scale tectonic domains that are (Fig. 1), from north to south, (1) the Fore-Caucasus superimposed on the Scythian Platform and comprising the Azov-Kuban Basin in the west and the Terek-Caspian Basin in the, east separated by the Stavropol High (Mikhailov et al., 1999); (2) the Greater Caucasus sensu lato forming the main topography; (3) the Transcaucasian domain, which consists of the Dzirula-Shatsky block (including the overlying Rioni and Kartli foreland basins) and the Ajara-Trialeti FTB bordering this block to the south (Tari et al., 2021b); (4) the Lesser Caucasus-South Caspian domain that spans the Mtkvari (Kura)-South Caspian Megadepression (Khain and Bogdanov 2006) and the former intra-island arc units of the Lesser Caucasus to the south (Artvin-Bolnisi block, Somkheto-Karabakh and Talysh FTB (Adamia et al., 2011; Sosson et al., 2016; Yilmaz et al., 2014); (5) and the South Armenian domain situated to the south of the Sevan-Akera suture zone and corresponding to the eastern part of the Taurides-Anatolides-South Armenian microplate (Sosson et al., 2010, 2016).
The Greater Caucasus orogen in the broad sense trends rectilinearly from the Kerch Strait, east of Crimea, to the Absheron Peninsula in eastern Azerbaijan (Khain, 1975). Its northern portion is formed by the southern edge of the Scythian Platform that is drawn and incorporated into the orogen in domains such as the uplifted Laba-Malka Homocline to the west and the Terek-Sunzha and Dagestan FTB to the east (Gamkrelidze and Shengelia, 2005; Khain, 1975; Sobornov, 1996, 2021
Yakovlev, 2012). The southern active deformation front of the GC orogen includes the offshore Tuapse Trough in the Black Sea (Almendinger et al., 2011; Nikishin et al., 2015), the Western Georgian Rioni foreland FTB (Tibaldi et al., 2017), and the Eastern Georgian-Azerbaijani Mtkvari (Kura)-Kartli foreland FTB (Forte et al., 2013; Mosar et al., 2010).
In a narrower sense however, and in the light of a paleotectonic affiliation, the Pshekish-Tyrnyauz Fault and the Racha-Lechkhumi Fault separate the GC from the Scythian Platform to the north and from the Transcaucasian domain to the south, respectively (Adamia et al., 1977; Khain, 1984, 2007; Yakovlev, 2012). The Main Caucasus Thrust (MCT) (Dotduyev, 1986) forms the largest internal fault and runs along strike the core of the GC core over more than 1000 km (Mosar et al., 2010; Yakovlev, 2012). Along the MCT's western part, pre-Mesozoic basement is exhumed (Main Range) (Somin, 2011), whereas in the east, it separates sedimentary rocks of Lower and Middle Jurassic ages (Mosar et al., 2010). The MCT divides the GC into a northern (the Main Range and Northern Slope) and southern domain (the Southern Slope) (Trifonov and Sokolov, 2014) and is considered as a major inherited structure of the former GC Basin axis.


3
The Greater Caucasus structure along the Georgian Military Road (Georgia – North Ossetia-Alania)
In order to densify existing information, we collected structural data in outcrops along, and in vicinity of the Georgian Military Road between Ananuri and the Georgia-Russia border in the Darial Gorge, i.e. along the rivers Aragvi and Terek (Tergi) and some tributary rivers (Fig. 2; supplemental material 1–3). Geological maps and published results pertaining to the structural geology of the North Caucasian (Russian) part of this area supplemented our field observations made in Georgia. Running between Tbilisi and Vladikavkaz, the Georgian Military Road is a major route passing the GC mountain belt across its axis and hence permits insight into its tectonic structure. At this longitude, the GC comprises in its core the Main Range zone framed to the south and north by the tectonic units of the Southern Slope zone and Northern Slope zone, respectively. Combining all available data with field observations we compiled a new geological-tectonic map of the area (Fig. 3
; see also detailed 1:100′000 map in supplemental material 1,2,3 and detailed map legend in supplemental material 4).

3.1
Structural zones of the Greater Caucasus

3.1.1
Main range
In respect to the topographic crest of the GC and its tectonic structure, the Main Range zone represents the most internal tectonic zone (Figs. 1–3). It builds up the core of the GC FTB and is delimited to the south by the Kazbegi thrust (local name of the MCT in the Military road area (Mosar et al., 2010)) and to the north by the Buron-Lars thrust, both mostly E-W striking structures. The Buron-Lars thrust may possibly correspond to the Psekish-Tyrnyauz Fault farther west in the central GC north of Mt Elbrus (Figs. 1 and 2). The Main Range zone comprises the oldest rocks along the investigated section, namely Upper Paleozoic granitic rocks exposed as the Dariali and Gveleti crystalline basement massifs (Gamkrelidze and Shengelia, 2005) brought to the surface along the steeply north-dipping Amali and Gveleti thrusts. The pre-Mesozoic basement massifs are witnesses of a polyphase geological history including the Baikalian, Caledonian, and Variscan events. They include Devonian-early Carboniferous arc-volcanism associated with supra-subduction zone ophiolites and numerous late-post Variscan intrusives of Permian age. Traces of Alpine deformation are widespread in the granitic rocks and expressed in form of folds, fractures, and cataclastic and mylonitic shear zones. Sinemurian to Toarcian folded terrigenous clastic rocks, mainly hemipelagic shales, are found around the massifs in tectonic contact. In places, the Sinemurian sediments overlay unconformably the granitic rocks, whereas at others Upper Carboniferous phyllite and quartzite (Gavrilov et al., 1999) constitute the lithological transition from crystalline basement to deep marine sedimentary basin fill. Across the Main Range zone, abundant dolerite sills and dykes intruded the granitic rocks of the Dariali and Gveleti massifs, as well as, the shales of Sinemurian-Pliensbachian age which form impressive cliffs and outstanding outcrops in the Stepantsminda area. Locally, the Pliensbachian shale hosts intercalated MORB-like tholeiitic basalts in form of agglomerates and pillow-lavas of Aalenian age (Adamia et al., 2011; Saintot et al., 2006). Their occurrence is restricted to the southern periphery of the Main Range zone in proximity to the MCT and to a tectonic klippe (Figs. 2 and 3), forming the outstanding Chaukhi mountain peaks (Fiagdon-Chauki “nappe”). The subvolcanic and subaqueous volcanic features in the Main Range zone relate to paroxysms of magmatic activity associated to important rifting and crustal extension in the GC Basin development throughout the Lower Jurassic and Aalenian (Adamia et al., 1977; Khain, 1975; Panov and Lomize, 2007).


3.1.2
Southern slope
The Southern Slope zone extends from the MCT in the north to the Kartli Basin in the south, and exposes the Lower Jurassic to Eocene fill of the former GC Basin in a succession of south to SSW-directed thrust slices, i.e. imbricates (Figs. 2 and 3). Four largely ESE-WNW trending tectonic subzones are recognized in the Southern Slope zone, each delimited by major thrusts and characterized by specific lithologies exposed at surface.
The Kazbegi-Lagodekhi zone features Toarcian to Bathonian argillaceous-sandy rocks, mainly hemipelagic shales, and extends from the MCT in the north to the Truso thrust in the south. The latter and the Gudauri thrust delimit the Upper Jurassic Kolosan-Pakhviji calciturbidite zone to the north and south, respectively. To the south, the Mestia-Tianeti flysch zone comprises Cretaceous to Eocene mainly siliciclastic and clastic limestone turbidite deposits. It lies south of the Gudauri thrust and overrides the Transcaucasian tectonic units to the south, i.e. the Gagra-Java zone and the Kartli Basin. Finally, the Ksani-Arkala parautochthonous zone, which exposes Aalenian sandy shales and Bajocian calc-alkaline volcaniclastics (“Porphyrite series”) in its core (Adamia, 2004; Gudjabidze and Gamkrelidze, 2003), forms an isolated and restricted thrust slice that was detached from the underthrusting Gagra-Java zone (Gamkrelidze and Kuloshvili, 1998). The frontal part of the Mestia-Tianeti zone, including the Ksani-Arkala zone, features a complex imbrication of southerly-directed thrust slices (“nappes”) (Leonov, 2016), where erosion subsequently exposed numerous tectonic windows and klippen that developed along flat lying thrusts (Gamkrelidze, 1991; Gamkrelidze and Gamkrelidze, 1977). Locally, in this part of the GC, the thrust slices contain late Eocene olistostrome deposits featuring predominantly olistoliths of Upper Jurassic reef limestone and Bajocian volcaniclastics (Maisadze, 2008). Outcrops throughout the Mestia-Tianeti flysch zone also feature syn-sedimentary structures in form of normal faults and slumped rock layers disrupting the regular bedding of the turbiditic deposits. They attest to the pre-collisional extensional character of the former GC Basin with structural high interpreted to be tilted blocks and to soft sediment slope instabilities that occurred within it.
The most striking feature of the Southern Slope zone is its exclusively south-vergent character of its E-W to ESE-WNW trending structures (Figs. 3–5

). The W-E to WNW-ESE regional structural trend is given by the bedding dip data, the thrust surface direction and the fold axes (also the cleavage/bedding intersection lineation (Figs. 4 and 5A).
The top-to-the-south movement is clearly expressed by the thrust orientation and dip to the N-NNE (Figs. 3 and 4; 5A), and the dipping of the fold axial surfaces to the N-NNE (Figs. 3 and 4; 5 A, B, C). The recurrence of Upper Cretaceous limestone flysch embedded in Lower Cretaceous siliciclastic flysch in the Mestia-Tianeti zone allows the distinction of a series of kilometric near-cylindrical folds, whose subhorizontal axes generally have an E-W orientation (Fig. 4). Across the Southern Slope zone, the Jurassic to Early Paleogene strata are deformed in tight to isoclinal folds. These southward inclined to overturned folds are associated to the southerly-directed throw along the thrusts during the Alpine inversion phase. Non-cylindrical folds with NW-plunging axes characterize the Kolosan-Pakhviji zone, in particular. Additionally, we can observe that fold axis are deviating fom there horizontal position and are sheared into the general thrust inclination towards the direction of transport. This can especially be seen in the Kolosan-Pakhveji Zone (Figs. 3, 4 and 5B, C), but also to the north and south, and is linked to the important shear component associated with the top-to-the south transport. The very low-grade metamorphic conditions (<300 °C) have favoured the formation of a penetrative rock cleavage that is found mostly in clay rich rocks (see also Vasey et al., 2020). Cleavage planes measured over the entire area of the Southern Slope are regularly dipping towards the north and are subparallel to the fold axial planes, and are thus identified as axial-planar cleavage concomitant to the folding and implicitly thrusting (Fig. 4). This foliation developed as fracture cleavage in the competent sandstone and limestone beds and as slaty and pencil cleavage in the clay-rich rocks.
Important deformation zones characterize and are indicative of the presence of major thrusts, particularly in road cuts in the Mestia-Tianeti zone along the Military Road (Fig. 5A). Here, the otherwise regularly north-dipping turbidite layers become increasingly deformed and dislocated in proximity to these thrust zones, resulting in local accumulation of small-scale reverse shear zones and folds. As a major discontinuity in the core of the GC, the MCT presents itself as a roughly 100 m wide deformation zone exposed by a steep road cut north of Stepantsminda (see also Vasey et al., 2020). The deformation induced by the top-to-the-south-directed throw along this thrust is expressed at different degrees over the thrust zone as discrete fault planes, shear zones and fault breccia and cataclasites in the Pliensbachian-Toarcian shales and dolerite intrusions. Measured reverse fault planes in the entire investigated area strike in average ESE-WNW to E-W and reflect the general trend of the larger-scale structures of the Southern Slope zone (Fig. 3; 5A).


3.1.3
Northern slope
The Northern Slope zone consists of two E-W trending tectonic subzones, the internal Digoro-Ossetian folded zone and the external Homocline Range zone. The Digoro-Ossetian zone extents north of the Main Range zone (Fig. 6
). Pre-Callovian, sandy-argillaceous Lower and Middle Jurassic rocks arranged in a series of north-directed thrust slices (Gavrilov et al., 1999) characterize this tectonic zone. Tight, north-vergent, overturned folds further indicate north-directed sense of movement along the thrusts. The degree of folding and cleavage intensity in this zone decreases steadily from south to north, i.e. from the internal towards the external part of the zone, and cleavage disappears completely towards the Homocline Range zone (Gavrilov et al., 1999). Overall, this reflects the transition from the folded domain to the uniformly dipping homoclinal parts of the Northern Slope zone. In the Homocline Range zone, the Upper Jurassic to Eocene platform-type carbonate-sandy rocks form a northward plunging homoclinal structure expressed at surface by a succession of E-W trending cuestas (the topography ranges from 3000m near the main range to 1000m in the northern foreland). South-directed movement along north-dipping thrusts that developed in Kimmeridgian-Tithonian evaporites of this zone (Sobornov, 1996), resulted in the doubling of the Upper Jurassic-Cretaceous lithological sequence and the subsequent emplacement of small tectonic klippen. The eastern part of the Homocline is in a transition zone to the eastern GS foreland north of Vladikavkaz, the east Dagestan foreland FTB (Mosar et al., 2010; Sobornov, 2021).
To the north, and constituting the foothills of the GC, Oligocene and Miocene at first euxinic (Maykop formation) then detrital molasse-type sediments of the Terek-Caspian Basin overlie the Homocline Range zone, locally in unconformable manner (Sobornov 1996, 2020). The Pliocene-Quaternary Akhchagilian-Apsheronian clastics, like in much of the Fore-Caucasus area, unconformably cover older rock formations of the Terek-Caspian Basin (Adamia et al., 2011; Mikhailov et al., 1999; Sobornov, 1996). East of Vladikavkaz, gentle anticlines and synclines developed in the sediments of the Terek-Caspian Basin as the continuation of westward plunging structures of the Northeastern GC (Dagestan FTB) (Pismennyi et al., 2006, Sobornov, 2020).



3.2
The Greater Caucasus - A doubly vergent fold-and-thrust belt
In agreement with Mosar et al. (2010), we interpret the GC orogen at the longitude of the Georgian Military Road as a doubly vergent FTB. Its pro-wedge includes the Southern Slope and northern Kartli Basin, whereas the retro-wedge developed in the Northern Slope and southern Terek Caspian Basin. From the core (Main Range zone) to the external parts of the mountain belt, the thrusting style evolves from thick-skinned crustal ramp-dominated to thin-skinned décollement-dominated. In general, both styles of deformation coexist along the belt (Mosar et al., 2010; Saintot et al., 2006).
In the subsurface, the Main Range zone forms a triangular shaped domain that is limited to the south by the MCT and to the north by steep back-thrusts. It contains a large antiformal structure that exposes the pre-Mesozoic basement massifs in its core, to form the highest summits of the GC. This central zone corresponds to the area of highest uplift observed in the GC and is associated to this triangular zone above the MCT (Mosar et al., 2010).
To the south, a succession of imbricated thrust slices with top-to-the south-west rooted in the basement, characterizes the tectonic structure of the pro-wedge. The wedge actively propagates southwards into its own Cenozoic foreland and thrusts onto the Transcaucasian Dzirula-Shatsky block (Khain, 2007), a basement culmination that is exposed transversally due to the orogenic loading of the GC and the Ajara-Trialeti belts on both sides (Banks et al., 1997). This basement ridge corresponds to the southern margin of the former GC basin. The pro-wedge incorporated the autochthonous Mesozoic-Early Cenozoic cover of this basement block (including the parautochthonous Gagra-Java zone) and actively deforms the overlying late Cenozoic foreland basin deposits of the Kartli Basin (Gamkrelidze, 1991; Banks et al., 1997; Gamkrelidze and Kuloshvili, 1998; Adamia et al., 2010), hence referred to as the Kartli foreland FTB. The GC pro-wedge, i.e. the Kartli foreland FTB (Tari et al., 2021a, 2021b), is bound to the south by the north-vergent structures of the Ajara-Trialeti FTB (Alania et al., 2015; Tari et al., 2021b).
According to (Sobornov, 1996, 2021), two stacked wedges that propagate northwards into the subsurface of the Terek-Caspian Basin define the structure of the retro-wedge in this part of the GC. This structures can be correlated to the East with the Dagestan foreland fold-and-thrust belt. The internal (lower) wedge is detached along a décollement that ramps from the basement in the mountain belt to the Tithonian evaporites of the Scythian Platform. Back-thrusts cutting across the Upper Jurassic-Cretaceous rocks constrain its roof. The wedge comprises a thrust duplex, whose stacking tilted the overlying sediments of the Scythian Platform and created the north-dipping homoclinal structure. The external (upper) wedge is floored and roofed by a flat hinterland-verging thrust in the Tithonian evaporites and a back-thrust in the Maykop mudstones, respectively. The arcuate Terek-Sunzha folded zone delimits this wedge to the north with the Terek anticline forming its northernmost structure at the surface. The tectonic wedging is accounted for the lack of surficial hinterland-verging (north-directed) thrusts in this part of the North Caucasus (Sobornov, 1994, 1996, 2021).
Thus, the small and medium scale structures observed in the field, and described in detailed profiles and on detailed geological maps, constrain our understanding of the larger subsurface built of the GC FTB. The prominent south-directed movement can be derived from the structures associated to thrusts and fold geometry. Thickness of layers and outcropping basement, both to the south and the north, help constrain the deeper structures and the thick-skinned tectonics (Figs. 3 and 6). This includes the central section where uplift is the most prominent and recent, the importance of the MCT and the doubly vergent geometry of the overal orogene. This latter aspect is especially support by the north-directed thrusting in the northern GC. This is clearly shown in the Dagestan foreland area (Sobornov, 1994, 1996, 2021), and has also been proposed and discussed in Mosar et al. (2010).
The beginning of the orogenic process and subaerial uplift can be dated as far back as earliest Oligocene, possibly even Eocene, following an important Paleocene unformity (Egan et al., 2009; Mosar et al., 2010; Vincent et al., 2016). Significant uplift started as early as earliest Oligocene (Avdeev and Niemi, 2011; Vincent et al., 2016a), with a post-Sarmatian age (∼12 My) climax as documented by Sarmatian marine shell found on the summit of Mount Shadhag (4250m) in N Azerbaijan (ref. in Mosar et al., 2010). Tectonic geomorphology studies in the southern foreland basin have demonstrated that anticlines are actively growing into the foreland (Forte et al., 2010, 2013, 2014b; Mosar et al., 2010) into the orogenic sedimentary foreland basin. Shortening rates between 6 and 14 mm/y are in agreement with geodetic data. Local shortening represents some 40% (Forte et al., 2013). Together, with information from seismicity and GPS, these latter studies reveal a still actively growing orogenic wedge (Ismail-Zadeh et al., 2020).



4
The Greater Caucasus prior to the Arabia-Eurasia collision
Previous works on the geodynamic evolution have largely described and constrained the different paleotectonic domains that existed during Mesozoic-Cenozoic times in the larger Caucasus region (e.g. Adamia et al., 1977; Barrier and Vrielynck, 2008; Dotduyev, 1986; Gamkrelidze, 1986; Golonka, 2004; Kazmin and Tikhonova, 2006; Khain, 1975; Nikishin et al., 2001, 2011; Panov and Lomize, 2007; Popov et al., 2004; Rolland, 2017; Sosson et al., 2010; Vincent et al., 2016). The focus hereafter lies on the paleotectonic and tectonosedimentary domains of the former southern part of the Eurasian continental plate, i.e. its southern margin and more specifically the Greater Caucasus Basin (Fig. 7
). The proposed paleotectonic reconstruction is a semi-quantitative restoration, based on our new regional section (Fig. 6) and on map information. We suggest that the structural inheritence from the paleotectonic setting determines the future nappe tectonics and development of distinct domains similarly as proposed in Mosar et al. (2010) and Egan et al. (2009) in the Eastern Greater Caucasus. Unlike numerous previously published basin reconstruction, we here propose a semi-quantitavely length balanced reconstruction, based on length/width and thicknesses that are taken from our section. We also use a concept of rift formation associated with asymmetric development of tilted blocks above listric faults and the formation of two rift shoulders (see also Mosar, 2003). The reconstruction proposed herein is at scale, and tries to apply realistic crustal/lithospheric dimensions.
The area situated north of the Lesser Caucasian-Pontian active margin, i.e. in a back-arc position (Adamia et al., 2011; Ershov et al., 2003; Golonka, 2004; Nikishin et al., 2001; Zonenshain and LePichon, 1986), consisted of a system of NW-SE trending extensional (thinned-crust) basins separated by basement horsts (Trifonov and Sokolov, 2014) and flanked by shelf-like platforms (Adamia et al., 2011; Guo et al., 2011; Dotduyev, 1986) showed the distribution of the main facies types including reefal complexes and associated this setting to the existence of two similar basin margins, to the north and to the south (Dotduyev, 1986). During the Early Cenozoic, the combined current territory of Georgia and the bordering Russian North Caucasus extended from the Lesser Caucasian volcanic arc to the south to the Scythian Platform to the north. It comprised two deep-marine intracontinental extensional basins with tilted block margin geometries, whose late Cenozoic tectonic inversion gave rise to the GC and Ajara-Trialeti mountain ranges (Mosar et al., 2010; Saintot et al., 2006; Vincent et al., 2016; Yilmaz et al., 2014). The GC Basin developed, as did subsequently the GC FTB, between the Scythian Platform to the north and the Transcaucasian Dzirula-Shatsky (Georgian) block to the south.
Since the Triassic, the Dzirula-Shatsky block formed a relatively uplifted shelf-like unit that flanked the GC Basin to the south (Vincent et al., 2016). The basement of this block is exposed as the present Dzirula Massif in Central Georgia and has been at near surface since the Late Paleozoic, indicated by unconformably onlapping Carboniferous, Mesozoic and Cenozoic sediments and volcaniclastics (Adamia et al., 2011; Mayringer et al., 2011; Vincent et al., 2016; Gamkrelidze and Shengelia, 2005). During the Mesozoic-Early Cenozoic, the southern shelf of the GC Basin shallow-water is characterized predominantly by carbonate sedimentation (Adamia et al., 2011; Vincent et al., 2016) accompanied during the Middle Jurassic by an important subduction-related andesitic and basaltic volcanism (Mengel et al., 1987). The Dzirula-Shatsky block retained its carbonate platform character throughout the Upper Jurassic, Cretaceous, Paleocene, and Early Eocene, exemplified by Upper Jurassic coral-dominated reefs that developed on its northern margin (Guo et al., 2011) and nummulitic limestones that accumulated on it in a shallow warm-water environment during most of the Ypresian and Lutetian times (Lygina et al., 2016). The northern margin of the Dzirula-Shatsky block is considered as a distinct zone, the Gagra-Java zone, characterized by the deposition of a thick island arc volcaniclastics interval during Bajocian times (Adamia et al., 2011) thought to be derived from the southren margin. The large Racha-Lechkhumi Fault separates the Gagra-Java zone from the Dzirula-Shatsky block and can be considered a bouding fault of a major tilted block at the southern margin of the GC Basin (s.l.) which has been inverted during alpine deformation. Cretaceous to Eocene intra-arc rifting separated the Dzirula-Shatsky block from the Lesser Caucasian (Artvin-Bolnisi and Somkheto-Karabakh) continental fragment, opening the deep-marine Ajara-Trialeti Basin (Adamia et al., 2011; Yilmaz et al., 2014). Thus, the isolated position of the Dzirula-Shatsky shelf between the GC Basin to the north and the Ajara-Trialeti basins and the Eastern Black Sea to the south explains the scarcity of siliciclastic material deposited there (Vincent et al., 2016).
The southern continental shelf of the Scythian Platform bordered the GC Basin to the north during the Mesozoic-Early Cenozoic (Fig. 7; Adamia et al., 2011; Adamia and Zakariadze, 2011; Ershov et al., 2003). Here, deposition of shallow-water siliciclastic sediments derived from the East European platform to the north dominated during Jurassic to Eocene times (Vincent et al., 2016). Coal lenses are a commonly observed feature in siliciclastics of the Sinemurian-Pliensbachian. Upper Jurassic coral reefs bordered the southern edge of the Scythian Platform shelf that are well preserved in the western GC (Dotduyev, 1986; Guo et al., 2011). During the Kimmeridgian-Tithonian, the western and especially the eastern domain of the Scythian shelf developed as a lagoon environment where deposition of evaporites occurred (Dotduyev, 1986; Mikhailov et al., 1999; Sobornov, 1996). The present Laba-Malka homoclinal zone in front of the Central GC corresponds to the uplifted southern margin of the Scythian Platform (Adamia et al., 2011; Khain, 1975; Sobornov, 1996; Yilmaz et al., 2014). This questa dominated landscape reaches up to altidues of 3000 m. a.s.l. Its complex, multiphase, basement is exposed as the Pre-Mesozoic units of the Bechasyn zone and the Fore Range (Gamkrelidze and Shengelia, 2005; Somin, 2011) and is overlain unconformably and in a generally northward onlapping manner by the Mesozoic shallow-water sediments of the continental shelf domain (Pismennyi et al., 2004). The basement of the Scythian Platform is characterized by a succession of inherited horst-and-graben paleostructures, e.g. the Fore Range that represents a Late Paleozoic depocenter between the then elevated Main Range and Bechasyn blocks and that was filled with Devonian to Permian volcano-sedimentary clastics (Upper Paleozoic “molasse”) (Somin, 2011). We consider the Pshekish-Tyrnyauz Fault as the northern boundary of the GC Basin given that the present Main Range features Lower-Middle Jurassic marine siliciclastics squeezed in narrow graben-synclines between the pre-Mesozoic basement blocks (Khain, 1975, 1984; Trifonov and Sokolov, 2014). Furthermore, the occurrence of Middle Jurassic dolerite sills and dykes, gabbroic and granitic batholiths (Somin, 2011), and MORB-like effusive rocks in the Main Range indicate that it pertained rather to the extensional basin domain than to the bordering platform domain or that it formed, at least, the basin-shelf transition, developing in a thinned continental crust.
In the light of the above-described pre-collisional tectonic setting, we interpret the Mesozoic-Early Cenozoic GC Basin at the latitude of the Georgian Military Road as an asymmetric rifted intracontinental basin of passive margin-type with numerous separate crustal blocks interpreted to be formed by crsutal-scale listric tilted blocks and associated half-grabens (Kalberguenova et al., 2018). The listric fault half-graben geometry is recognize from profiles in the northern GC and can be deduced from outcrop exposures in the central uplifted pre-Mesozoic basement. The detailed geometry of the paleotectonic structures in the main GC basin remains largely unknown and we here propose a classic listric fault driven tilted-block and halfgraben geometry.
The extension induced by the back-arc rifting intensely thinned the continental crust underlying the GC Basin, leading to partial melting of the asthenosphere and development of associated MORB-like tholeiitic magmatism during the Middle Jurassic. During the Alpine stage, subsequent to the Late Eocene-Oligocene Arabia-Eurasia collision, the rifted and tilted blocks were structurally inverted along the listric normal faults that were reactivated as south-directed thrusts hence developing the Southern Slope imbricate fan. The main crustal detachment fault was reactivated as a deep-seated low-angle thrust in the subsurface of the East Georgian GC. These major faults host the bulk of the deformation associated with the GC development and remain active, as exemplified by earthquake focal mechanisms and ongoing seismicity identified along the thrust interpreted in our tectonic cross section (Fig. 6; Tan and Taymaz, 2006; Legendre et al., 2017). The frontal part of the Southern Slope zone, complicated by numerous thrust slices and characterized by tectonic-gravitational mixtite (linked to inverted crustal tilted blocks), is restored as the junction between the Transcaucasian Dzirula-Shatsky basement block (including the Gagra-Java zone) and the deep flysch basin with thinned crust (Leonov, 2016). The MCT represents a reactivated major extensional fault that was in proximity to the axis of the basin, i.e. where the continental crust was the most thinned, due to the local accumulation of crustal extension-related magmatic features (batholiths, dolerite sills/dykes, and pillow lavas). Recent dating of shear zones along the MCT indicate Jurassic ages (190-135 Ma) and corroborate our interpretation (Vasey et al., 2020).


5
Conclusion
Extensive fieldwork combined with a compilation of existing data, along the Georgian-Russian military road and in the near vicinity, made it possible to re-assess the tectonic architecture of the Greater Caucasus mountain range. A new compiled and revised geological-tectonic map allowed us to revisit, and locally re-define the major structural units and their relevance in both the paleotectonic and alpine tectonic setting.
The Greater Caucasus is an actively propagating doubly verging fold-and-thrust belt resulting from the tectonic inversion of a Mesozoic-Early Cenozoic intracontinental rift. This Greater Caucasus Basin initiated during the Lower Jurassic and evolved into a hyperextended continental lithospheric basin in the southern Eurasia margin as a consequence of Mesozoic extensional tectonics induced and controlled by the northward Neotethys subduction located to the south (Cimmerian stage). As such the basin evolved in a back-arc setting north of the active margin of the Lesser Caucasus. The continued Arabia-Eurasia convergence and subsequent collision in the Late Eocene-Oligocene led to the closure of this deep marine basin, resulting in the inversion of the inherited extensional structures and formation of important underthrusting and stacking of tectonic units (Alpine stage) and the formation of an important orogenic wedge.
Our study along the Georgian Military Road (Eastern Georgia - North Ossetia-Alania) highlights the tectonic units and confirms the doubly verging structure that builds up the eastern Central Greater Caucasus fold-and-thrust belt. Thus, the pro-wedge of the orogen comprises the south-verging Southern Slope imbricate fan (deformed Mesozoic-Early Cenozoic basin fill) whose active deformation front reaches far to the south into the post-Eocene Kartli foreland basin, which itself evolved from a purely flexural stage into a wedge top setting. The Transcaucasian Dzirula-Shatsky block is actively underthrusting the Greater Caucasus orogen. The retro-wedge of the north GC incorporates, from the core of the mountain belt (basin axis) to its hinterland (Scythian Platform), the Main Range, a triangular-shaped structure uplifted along the Main Caucasus thrust, and the Northern Slope duplex stack that wedged to the north creating the homoclinal structure that is characteristic of the central North Caucasus.
Detailed structural investigation allowed us to document and confirm the thrust and fold geometry and the associated kinematics. The regional fold trend and thrust orientation is W-E to WNW-ESE. South of the basement units of the Main Range, the main transport direction is top-to-the south with an important shear component that can be recognized in a strain concentration in the major thrust zones, and regionally also by a gentle reorientation of fold axes into the transport direction. Associated with the fold development, a slaty cleavage develops under low-grade metamorphic conditions, espacially in the domains of the Southern Slope.
We restored the present tectonic units of the Greater Caucasus to their pre-collisional counterparts in a rifted basin setting, characterized by numerous tilted basement blocks, between what was the Scythian Platform shelf to the north and the Dzirula-Shatsky shelf to the south. Accordingly, the units of the Southern Slope imbricate fan spanned the southern portion of the Greater Caucasus basin from the Dzirula-Shatsky horst to the south to the axial part of the basin to the north. The Lower-Middle Jurassic basaltic magmatic basin axis is preserved as the southernmost portion of the Main Range zone today. The Main Range and the Northern Slope are interpreted as the portion of the basin located to the north of the basin axis, hence forming the transition towards the Scythian Platform shelf. Major thrusts of the orogen (e.g. Main Caucasus Thrust, Pshekish-Tyrnyauz Fault, and Racha-Lechkhumi Fault) correspond to inherited, normal listric detachments of the former extensional rift, that were reactivated as reverse faults during the Alpine inversion stage. The MCT is thus a major, and still active, structure separating the core and northern slopes of the GC orogen from the southern slopes, as well as a major inherited, extensional fault located in the GC basin center.
Integrating existing data, densified by fieldwork, made it possible to propose a new unified tectonic map of the area of investigation, which subsequently allowed us to propose a new paleotectectonic model, based on modern understanding of rift formation.
